Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5NVF-4TT1-JBHT-D0KY-00000-00Profit from Experience; Airlines Eye the Heat; Daisy Carnival Heats Up; Georgia Heads to the Polls; South Carolina Elections;2017-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisProfit from Experience; Airlines Eye the Heat; Daisy Carnival Heats Up; Georgia Heads to the Polls; South Carolina Elections;LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Tuesday, June 20th. Here are your top stories 6:00 A.M. on the East Coast.

President Trump takes aim at North Korea after Otto Warmbier dies days after returning to the United States with severe brain damage. The company that took into the country now saying it will no longer take Americans there. It says a tragedy like this should never be repeated.

Meanwhile on Capitol Hill, a push for reform this morning. "The Wall Street Journal" reporting a health care vote will take place next week. The administration holding firm that tax reform will also get done this year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. SECRETARY OF TREASURY: I have no higher priority than having tax reform done this year. We're working every day. We're working with the house and the senate. We're committed to get this done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Plus, a contentious moment between Senators Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer coming up.

It is technically not even summer. But the southwest is facing a dangerous heat wave this morning. Temperatures already near triple digits today. We will give you the latest.

And the heat taking a toll. American Airlines has cancelled more than a dozen flights. More than 1,000 needed medical attention at the Electric Daisy Concert in Las Vegas.

Markets look like this this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating a mixed opening for the broader averages. Fractionally better on the session. The Dow and the S&P coming up of a record close yesterday. Looking to extend that today with fractional moves in the upside. Dow Industrial sets to open up about 10 points. Ditto for the NASDAQ.

In Europe, the indices look like this. Take a look. European indices higher across the board with the CAC quarante in Paris, best performer up about a third of a percent.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower, meanwhile. Take a look. As you see the best performer was the Nikkei in Japan that was up one percent. The others down fractionally.

Tom Brady wants to play an NFL game outside of the U.S. We will reveal where he says is his dream country to play one day. All those stories coming up this morning.

And joining me to talk about it, financial analyst Heather Zumarraga is with us. Wall Street Journal assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman is with us. And the London Center for Policy Research, Vice President Lieutenant Colonel Tony Shaffer is here. Great to see you.

TONY SHAFFER, LONDON CENTER FOR POLICY RESEARCH: Great seeing you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: What's on top this morning, James? What do you think of the big stories?

FREEMAN: Well, at long last, patients, doctors, taxpayers may finally see the beginning of the end of ObamaCare.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. They were looking for a vote next week. So we'll see that. We will talk about all of that this morning.

Coming up joining the conversation, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross is with us today. Tennessee Congresswoman Marsha Blackburn is with us today. Fox News Military analyst, Jack Keane is here. Harvard law professor emeritus Alan Dershowitz is here. And former Raegan campaign advisor, Ed Rollins is here as well. You don't want to miss moments of it. So just stay with us throughout the show.

We kick it off this hour right now with Otto Warmbier. The American student imprisoned in North Korea for 17 months and sent back to the United States in a persistent vegetative state last week, died yesterday. He died at the tender age of 22 years old. Doctors treating the University of Virginia student said late last week that Warmbier had extensive loss of brain tissue and he was in the state of unresponsive wakefulness.

Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in North Korea for allegedly stealing a propaganda poster during an organized tour to the isolated country. The Chinese company behind Young Pioneer Tours, the tour company that sent him there now says it will stop taking U.S. citizens to North Korea.

President Trump weighed in on the sad news from the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Otto Warmbier has just passed away. He spent a year and a half in North Korea. A lot of bad things happened. But at least we got him home to be with his parents where they were so happy to see him, even though he was in very tough condition.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Warmbier's parents Fred and Cindy put the blame squarely at North Korea writing in a statement, "Unfortunately the awful torturous mistreatment our son received at the hands of the North Koreans ensure that no other outcome was possible beyond the sad one we experienced today.

Tony, your take on these developments.

SHAFFER: Well, look, there's no doubt in my mind he was tortured. Let's be very clear what happened here. And I've already said another interviews I think there needs to be some level of retaliation. I'll just be that direct about it. My son is 23. I cannot imagine the pain these parents are going through. This is truly tragic.

My understanding from talking to the experts, he was tortured not so much the way where you'd be pulling fingernails out with tools, but by repeated drugging, sodium pentothal. The idea was they were trying to figure out if he was a CIA spy or not. He wasn't. And the continued and repeated exposure over that year to these drugs is what caused the consistent and persistent damage of the entire brain. So it was essentially the use of these drugs over and over again which caused the brain damage.

BARTIROMO: Now, there were some reports that he went into the vegetative state just recently, a couple of weeks ago. So, was that --

SHAFER: I don't buy that. I think this --

BARTIROMO: The whole time you think he was just drugged?

SHAFFER: I think they started during his confinement and did it over and over. And I think of the reasons they released him --I mean no doubt, President Trump saw this and started dealing with it early on. But no doubt they kind of like saw that some things are going to go tragically wrong. We better get this guy out of here, anyway. So let's serve their purpose to get him out.

The parents got their boy back, their son back. But again, Maria, it does not change the fact that he was tortured. This is something that we should not stand for. And I believe that President Trump recognizes how hideous this is and something requires a response.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And what kind of response do you expect? Should be warranted.

SHAFFER: We in the Cold War, we had organizations which focused on is what they called dirty tricks in the old days. Look, we need to rethink our foreign policy. We cannot simply sit back and let dictators, horrible people like Kim Jong-un do these things and think they can get away with it. There's been no push back. This is a remote analogy. But we just shut down a certain aircraft. We haven't shut down an aircraft since 1999. So I think it's time we re-insinuate ourselves in foreign policy in a way that the -- those bad guys like Un understand there's going to be consequences for bad behavior. There's been no bad consequences for decades.

BARTIROMO: And Otto's parents said that. Look, President Obama told us to be quite. President Trump took our son home. James, how do you see it?

FREEMAN: Well, this is one of the last to the old style dictatorships. This is what communists, dictatorships so. I think it was probably surprising to a lot of people over the last year following this news that you actually tend to travel to North Korea. To this point, the state department has a -- had a strong warning and I think maybe you'd expect from now it would be something more like a -- like a band -- I mean, obviously they don't treat visitors any better than they treat their own people. And this -- for anyone who didn't realize that, yes, this is a wake up call.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, FINANCIAL ANALYST: But so maybe we should it be there though. There are some -- to some extent, we shouldn't be going to these places.

BARTIROMO: But this was a tour company from China, Heather. I mean, if you've got a tour company, you may be thinking that you're OK and that you're with a safe group.

Let's switch gears to the standoff in the senate right now. Because this is also a piece of important business today. Republicans are aiming for a vote on the health care bill next week. A full week ahead of the July 4th recess since the democrats have begun using parliamentary maneuvers to slow down business in the chamber though to protest any bill including a series of back to back speeches on the floor yesterday.

In one exchange, minority leader Chuck Schumer press his counterpart, Mitch McConnell to commit to an open debate. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), MINORITY LEADER: When we have time more than 10 hours, since this is a complicated bill to review the bill, will it be available to us and the public, more than 10 hours before we have to vote for it.

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), MAJORITY LEADER: I think we'll have an ample opportunity to read and amend the bill.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Do you see republicans pushing through to get this done before July 4th, James Freeman? And also, what's your take on this ostracism? They're basically telling you in advance. Look, we're going to do long speeches. We're going to do whatever it takes to waste time so this doesn't get done?

FREEMAN: Yes. So a lot of theatrics. I think the republicans will get it done. It's interesting there. You look at Chuck Schumer saying, I want 10 hours to read bill. Of course, if you took another clip from that speech he was saying, as he often does that this is a terrible bill and he's opposed to it. So he's not -- he's not an over minded voter here looking to consider the measure. He doesn't need 10 hours. He's already against it without even having seen it because this is the Obama legacy project, no matter how bad it's failing. They have tied themselves to it politically and they're going to do well of the parliamentary moves they can do to slow it down but they can't and it'll pass.

BARTIROMO: Is there any chance though that they are able to stop any business whatsoever that the Trump administration trust to put forth? That's the whole plan. Let his president be a president that gets nothing done. Let this congress be get nothing done congress that we take the house in '18 and we impeach him in '20?

FREEMAN: I don't think that will work. Because if you basically make it impossible to do business, what they're going to do is they're going to kill the legislative filibuster which still exists and allows them to block things like -- any measure that can't get 60 votes. Now, health care is different because they're going through this recompilation process. But basically if they put up a big roadblock like they did with Gorsuch, it' going to hurt their agenda because they're not going to be able to stop anything else. It seems a lot of republicans are going to say, enough. We're going to filibuster.

BARTIROMO: All right. So then you do think a health care vote happens?

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let me ask you about House Speaker Paul Ryan. He sets to deliver his first major speech on tax reform today. According to the excerpts of the speech that have been released, he's expected to urge republicans, "We need to get his done in 2017. We cannot let this once in a generation moment slip."

Now, Heather, if we don't see tax reform, big implications from markets?

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, the markets have been up hitting all-time highs. Yet again, I think Futures are up today. We'll see if the Dow can hit new highs today. It's tax reform. It's health care. That's what it's all about. That's what the markets are running on right now.

BARTIROMO: James, what do you want to hear from Paul Ryan today?

FREEMAN: I'd like to hear him say that the number one priority is growing this economy.

BARTIROMO: That's what he's going to say. You know that.

FREEMAN: Well, I'm worried that he's also going to say that this has got to be revenue natural. We've got to stick with the conventions of beltway score keeping no matter how flawed they are.

BARTIROMO: Right. And that means the border adjustment tax or higher corporate rate or some kind of a revenue, right?

FREEMAN: They've got to get the corporate rate into the teams if we want a real game changer.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Tony?

SHAFFER: Look, I think what we've seen over and over again is reluctant facts to actually break out of what we know doesn't work. The scoring system, we know doesn't work, doesn't matter. The democrats always refer to it. And what I don't understand why the republicans haven't gone back and looked at the numbers that CBO did on the original estimates for ObamaCare and look at how wildly of they were. So it's kind of like how is that you don't just look at what bad work they did and say throw it out because it doesn't work.

BARTIROMO: You're right. It's funny to hear Chuck Schumer say, well, when you do things in the dark of night. Excuse me, ObamaCare was done in the dark of night.

ZUMARRAGA: No. Find out what's in the bill after we pass the bill.

BARTIROMO: Nancy Pelosi. We have the Trump tweets to tell you about the president is tweeting this morning. And we want to bring you to you right now President Trump just tweeting about the Georgia special election. "Democrat Jon Ossoff who wants to raise your taxes to the highest level and is weak on crime and security doesn't even live in the district. Karen Handel for congress, she will fight for lower taxes, great health care, strong security. A hard worker who will never give up. Vote today.

We've got more analysis on this. The special election happening in Georgia. Of course it's real important. It's the most money, right? In the congressional election.

FREEMAN: Ossoff has raised more than 23 million bucks. He's got about five times the money that Karen Handel has. He's raising his money basically outside of Georgia. So it's going to be a question of whether people want to -- Georgia voters want to allow the rest of the country's liberals to use them as a vehicle to oppose the president.

BARTIROMO: Does this tell us anything, I mean, if Ossoff wins or Handel wins, does this tell us anything about the republican party or democratic party today do you think? Is this going to be sort of an indicator?

SHAFFER: Well, Georgia has been one of the states that the democrats have been trying to turn for a while. I mean, there was during the last election cycle, I believe, which was not founded on anything real that they could turn this state blue and they didn't. But I think you see over and over again, every election, we've seen special cycle election, outside money's been donated heavily and they've lost every time. And I think it's going to happen again here because the overwhelming feeling still is that I think people want to give President Trump time to get his act together. I think this is a microcosm of other things. And Georgia still I think is more red than blue.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. We'll take a short break. We have a lot more on the congressional race today.

BARTIROMO: That's amazing. So it's just the fact that you're right near the route of where this -- the drugs are coming in?

PLUMMER: Yes, yes. It's a perfect storm for us saying, you know, they need more resources from the federal government.

BARTIROMO: So, the President has taken executive action by forming a commission to combat drug addiction and this opioid crisis. You want to see funding from the government? What else do you want from the government in terms of addressing this in Montgomery County?

PLUMMER: We need funding, we need more boots on the ground, you know, we all been - we've had a bad economic downturn, we've lost a lot of officers, so we need more resources on the ground because we have to work on this through the supply - the supply how much is coming from Mexico. We have to work on the demand, we have to treat our users and have to get into prevention and education to keep the next generation from falling into this trap.

FREEMAN: Hi, James Freeman here with the Journal. Speaking about education, I know a lot of programs around the country or a lot of schools have these DARE programs, police officers educating kids starting at a very young age. Is there something related to that or not doing as you see this particular epidemic, is there somebody parents ought to be doing that we're not?

PLUMMER: Yes. People -- there is a lot of understanding about the opioid crisis, so what we're starting now is we're having town hall meetings and all of our churches, we need to get the congregations to our -- in front of our panelists and educate them on what's going on and what to be aware of, you know, how to protect your children. I, mean, we're losing our kids every day here in this community.

SHAFFER: I have a follow-up question, Sheriff, on the issue of how the stuff is coming into the region and what you guys are doing about it. Is there any way to try to go after the money? I mean, I work kind counterdrug in the 90s, and obviously the financial motives for this sort of thing by those who control the flow if you - if you start going right at the money, that's one issue. So have you guys been able to look at who's dealing this? You mentioned some of the folks transporting this. I know you can't necessarily get ahead of the pipeline but there are certain things you can do to take the financials and (INAUDIBLE) you guys look at how to get at the financial aspects of this at all.

PLUMMER: Yes. We've done - we've been targeting the cartel members, we have two cartels, Mexican cartels bringing the product to our community. So, you know, we've been watching them in various hotels and we've been trying to capture the moneys. And the last couple of years, we've taken $5.5 dollars cash off of the streets from the cartels that would have gone back to Mexico.

SHAFFER: Wow. Good.

PLUMMER: Yes. So, unfortunately, that's not working either. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Ohio is suing top pharmaceutical companies. They say allegedly they downplayed the risk of addiction to drive sales, Purdue Pharma, Johnson and Johnson, Allergan, among those facing these lawsuits. Do you agree with that? Is some of the blame on these pharmaceutical companies?

PLUMMER: Yes. Yes. Definitely, they have some accountability here. And, you know, and I support the lawsuits but unfortunately, that's a long-term solution for this problem and we've been fighting this problem for four years. So, we need some immediate resources here in this community.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching. Sheriff, thanks very much for weighing in and explaining the story to us. We appreciate it. Sheriff Phil Plummer joining us. Montgomery County there. Coming up. D.C. has Georgia on its mind today. The polls are open in the race for HHS Secretary, Tom Price's congressional seat. The election happening today, why it is critical for both parties, we'll take you there. Then tune into Snapchat, a T.V. giant pouring millions since programming for the popular app. The reaction from investors, stock is down half of a percent right now. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Happy Tuesday. Welcome back, everybody. Thank you so much for joining us. It is Tuesday, June 20th. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And here are your top stories, 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. A busy day at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue today. President Trump will host the president of the Ukraine at the White House later this afternoon. The meeting comes amid rising tensions in our nation's capital. A new poll shows a vast majority of Americans believe political debate is becoming increasingly uncivil and it is encouraging violence. The trend is sure to be on voters' minds as they head to the polls in Georgia today.

KAREN HANDEL, GEORGIA CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: I feel great, very, very encouraged by things the enthusiasm on the ground has been amazing.

JON OSSOFF, GEORGIA CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: I think this is an opportunity for Georgia to elect some fresh leadership that's focused on delivering results for folks at home, focus on what people that kind (INAUDIBLE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Over 140,000 ballots have already been cast as Jon Ossoff and Karen Handel vie for the empty House seat latest on a special election in Georgia and South Carolina, this morning. Jack Ma making a big push in the U.S. the Alibaba founder in is Detroit today, and in efforts to make good on his promise to create jobs in America. Details on his plan to impress entrepreneurs and President Trump. And Amazon's massive deal for whole foods could bring major changes to the checkout counter what the acquisition means for the future of the cashier in your shopping.

And then Brown wants you to pay a little more green this holiday season, the new deliveries fee you could be facing, from UPS this Christmas. Oil prices are driving the action for stock prices this morning, crude oil is down better than two percent right now and that has taken the wind out of gains for stock prices, there's oil down $1.13, that's 21/2 percent at $43.07 a barrel on oil sweet crude.

Futures meanwhile are also their high take a look at stocks here and the Dow Industrials averages now negative expected to open down about seven points. S&P is also negative both the Dow and the S&P hit record highs yesterday at the close. The Nasdaq is swill positive although it is well off of the highs of the morning, in Europe, similar situation, as oil has reversed course and worsened, European markets have also done so. The F.T. 100 is down eight points, the CAC Quarante and the DAX Index are up but just fractionally. And Asia overnight markets closed mostly lower with the exception of Japan it was up one percent.

Americans on both sides of the aisle now say the tone and level of civility in our political debate is getting much worse according to a new poll by CBS News, 68 percent of Americans across all parties said so while just seven percent said the tone was getting better, better? Three-quarters of Americans also say they feel the current tone of political debate is encouraging violence, joining us right now the Trump great America PAC and Co-Chair and former Reagan campaign manager Ed Rollins is here, Ed great to see you.

ED ROLLINS, REPUBLICAN CAMPAIGN CONSULTANT AND ADVISOR: Thank you, thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: What do you think of this?

ROLLINS: Obviously there is the rhetoric is much more severe than it's ever been, and it's been increasing over last 20 years to a point since the Trump election, now their people are very unhappy their very polarized, you either for Trump or totally against Trump, and actually to me I can't go to restaurant anywhere in this country that I hear someone, not adjacent table talking about politics, I've never seen that before and one sense that's good because their paying attention another sense is not particularly positive conversations.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but it's also, you know, you have Hollywood getting in on the act Robert De Niro saying I want to punch the President in the face you've got Madonna saying yes I think about blowing up the White House then, of course, the sickest of them all with Kathy Griffin and her head that she was holding that time.

ROLLINS: I think Hollywood is proven to be totally irrelevant in the last election when everybody was pretty much for MRS. Clinton didn't make any difference. I think the serious thing here though is we could have had a massacre last week if those two Capitol guards had not been there guarding, you know, they could have killed 10 members of Congress or more and I think that's very severe that, you know, this is a deranged guy this is obviously someone who that just walked on the field that morning, he had planned this but it's very, very severe.

TONY SHAFFER, RETIRED UNITED STATES ARMY: And I said the other day in interview that I felt that the essentially there's a pathology here and that pathology mirrors what ISIS has been doing to radicalize its members, I mean you're talking about a group where you have certain beliefs which become completely inculcated in your believers to the point of were even that they believe fiction they believe the whole Russian there, there was on the other and then you have on top of that then this desensitization of the groups by media. Media saying it's OK, to say you want to punch the President, it's OK to have the image of President Trump being behead and then that leads them to people acting out. So I believe that we're on a path of seeing more of this world thing based on the fact that the left refuses completely to acknowledge the fact that they are radicalizing individuals to act.

ROLLINS: But the bottom line is both sides have let a tone a down a little bit there's some very serious we have to debate in the very near future. The irony is we just haven't a Congressional race today this most expensive race in the history of the country, over $50 million has been spent on a Congressional race just to put that in the proper perspective. When I ran Reagan 49 state victory we spent $40 million so the publicly financed campaign $50 million on a singular Congressional pain. I ran a Congressional committee in numbers of years ago and my whole budget was in $50 million here in and across the country. So the irony here is this to be interpreted as a Trump victory or Trump defeat in which Trump really didn't play very much of a part, the Democrats running as a new Democrat, Karen Handel was one of very, very effective race on the start of the close I can't tell who's going to win but it's a dead even race today with more money spent than ever before.

BARTIROMO: This is so incredible and by the way, Jon Ossoff doesn't even live in the district, right?

ROLLINS: He's two hours outside the district.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP FUNDS: And although have Trump had a little to do with this race, what does this mean for the Trump agenda going forward?

ROLLINS: Specials are always over-interpreted and their totally different dug and it's five or six specials every cycle between the elections. But this clearly if Handel wins, the Trump people certainly well justifiably argue to their benefit if not the Democrats will argue this is a rejection of Trump even though Trump really was a debater very much and a course.

BARTIROMO: And this is a Republican district all the way back to a red new days.

ROLLINS: This is (INAUDIBLE) this is the district he first won.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

ROLLINS: The Democrats have changed slightly and I don't think you should over-interpreted but it's an Atlantic District It's a big media market, but it's some time want to watch very closely.

BARTIROMO: James.

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASSISTANT EDITOR EDITORIAL PAGE: I've just want to relate, this Ossoff message he's a former staff or for very liberal Democratic member of Congress, he's raised money from Democrats all around the country calling himself independent. When people ask him if his force Nancy Pelosi, he said he hadn't given them an ounce of thought. Is that possibly true?

ROLLINS: No.

BARTIROMO: And then talks an independent, no.

ROLLINS: And I promise you if he gets elected tomorrow or tonight which I hope doesn't happen, he'll be played Nancy Pelosi is going to first words out of his mouth and he thanked you, madam leader, where do I sit? And how do I vote, I think that's the key thing.

SHAFFER: Do you think it's working?

ROLLINS: It's worked there, I mean, it's a -- again, it's not as much a Republican district as it used to be, Trump carried the district by about two points in the fall. And again I don't want to be over-interpreted I just think it's, it is going to have an impact on recruiting in a certain. We're going to talk about first few days here but it's not the end game.

BARTIROMO: Wow it's a real plead heat and voters are also headed to the polls in South Carolina and the South Carolina fifth district. This is to fill the seat of the one, formerly held on Mick Mulvaney, that hasn't got nearly as much attention but this is also an important race.

ROLLINS: Two important race all over the Democrats have an wait much of a battle there. So we should win that race in for some reason they come close the Democrats without spending much money then that I think of South Carolina is a more of an indicator of what's occurring here. I think the reality here is we're going to move full, that's a very tough battles ahead and I think the polarization that were talking about in the beginning of this segment is very severe in the Congress and the problem is there's not enough, Republicans don't have enough Republicans to do all of things they want to do, even if they have majority and there's not enough money for both sides to do all that they want to do.

BARTIROMO: One of the things they want to do is repeal and replace Obamacare, they say that there is going to be a vote in the Senate next week Ed, and then they are talking about tax reforms after the summer. Do you still think the agenda getting executed as viable this year?

ROLLINS: I think it's tough, I think no one holds what's in the Senate bill and Senator McConnell it's pretty much his bill so the few people getting their advice, it's still not poputive a House bill was overwhelm not (INAUDIBLE). However it comes out as a big selling job that has to take place there's only one person that can sell it, and that's the President. The President has to go out across this country and the only criticism I have of the President today is you can't do one-day events, you can't go out and say today is infrastructure day and tomorrow is tech day and what you have. If he wants to sell health care he's going to be out there every day for weeks and weeks and weeks telling American public why this is going to work and why it's better than Obamacare.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point, Ed.

SHAFFER: On the issue of Senate and from what they're doing with the health care bill, I see a lot of changes coming that's going to have to go into some sort of a reconciliation between the House again. Quick question do you see the House staying though August? Do you see that the potential have actually -

ROLLINS: I wish they would but that's what (INAUDIBLE) wish thanking for, odd realistic.

BARTIROMO: They have talked about it, right?

ROLLINS: They have talked about it but the bottom-line is they never gave that up, they've all got junkyards that are all going back home and they've got vacation plans like everybody else. I just wish they wouldn't take so many vacations, I think this is very serious year, we've got some very big issues today the speakers speech is going to be very, very important on the tax - what is his tax plan has the guy knows more about the taxes than anybody and he's going to basically give anything or that basically don't know about so far. I think getting this tax plan through a tax reform is critical, I think health care is important but I think tax is critical -

ZUMARAGGA: It's also critical for the stock market and were reaching all- time highs because of tax reform may happen -

ROLLINS: It's the hope and so for some reason, we go to the next two months and we don't think it's going to happen, I think markets going to change.

FREEMAN: Well it's also Republicans political survival next fall is they're going to get the economy growing faster.

ROLLINS: That's the promise the President made the rest of it is totally relevant. The international stuff that he's all dealing with it is critical as part of any Presidents responsibility but what he promised the American public, so I'm going to fix the economy and I want to create jobs your lives going to be better and there's a whole lot of stuff has to happen for that.

BARTIROMO: That is what is going to leave voters in 2018, for the next group of elections, do you think voters will remember the way that the left has been obstructing and basically pushing back on the agenda that America voters -

ROLLINS: I think the problems is you have both sides are very polarized, so Democrats aren't being turned off by this activity and Republicans, the same way, it's so if two very anti entities out there and I think the bottom line is those that are independents and the worry that I think Trump has is that some of the independents who voted for him in the fall are starting to back away and independents carry the day today.

FREEMAN: OK. And just given that we had this attempted assassination last week, do you think it's time for Democrats to stop calling themselves the resistance?

ROLLINS: Yes.

FREEMAN: As if they are French freedom fighters battling the Nazis -

ROLLINS: They're very important that the rhetoric get toned down, I mean you can go fight on the floor, and make whatever kinds of comments you want, but you got cut stop this personal attack and you got to quit basically making enemies out of the opposite side. Part of the breakdown I've been around the game 50 years is it used to be there was social you can still fight still be partisan.

BARTIROMO: But you go have a cup of coffee.

ROLLINS: Still have a couple coffee or drink or dinner what have you, you have to know his at his family's and you realize we're all Americans today they don't sit together they don't talk together staffers don't meet together and they just are polarized they hate each and that's other a terrible place to be.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean listen to Chuck Schumer yesterday, saying that, you know, they are passing something in the dead of night as if nobody remembers the way Obamacare was passed, and stuck down everybody's throat.

ZUMARAGGA: And that what he said you'll find out what's in the bill when it is passed.

BARTIROMO: That's what Nancy Pelosi said.

ROLLINS: And unfortunate all those words are going to coming back this time if we don't do it differently and that's my concern at this point in time. I think we got to get this thing drafted I don't have any problems Senator McConnell of doing it. I just think it has to get very open we're going to have a big debate on it, people have to know what this is all about if not we'll pay a heavy price.

ZUMARAGGA: And we'll give Chuck Schumer more than 10 hours, to see what's in the bill.

BARTIROMO: He wants for this than ever that's what he said as well. Ed great to see you

ROLLINS: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much great insights as always from Ed Rollins. Coming up Amazon's deal to acquire whole foods could send cashiers packing the potential trouble ahead for grosser is it going robotic? And then Santa sleigh make come with a surcharge where the shipping giant is planning to charge more for holiday delivery there were at UPS, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. With O&M, head of Chinese e-commerce giant, Alibaba is rolling into mortar city. Here's Nicole Petallides covering the story from New York, Stock Exchange. Hi, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you, Maria. That is right. Technology and e-customers wave off the future. The story was exactly that Jack Ma, Chairman of Alibaba, is coming into moderate gateway conference and is going to meet with over 3,000 businesses all to go with the pledge to President Donald Trump in creating jobs. Alibaba has already done millions and millions of jobs in China and China e-commerce. By the way, the only sales reported are 771 billion clearly out places that are in the United States. This year, it is at 446 billion in the hopes of trying to get U.S. businesses to now work with Alibaba. That in itself is a big deal.

Jack Ma also has power in bringing head of UPS in order to make this deal happen. There are concerns because you have these sellers lacking the clarity of merchandise and can step in trying to woo U.S, besides creating jobs to Amazon -- we know Amazon made that nearly $14 billion deal with Whole Foods. Reports are now going to use strategy of Amazon so that customers can now walk around the store with no cashiers, just technology sensors, streamers, and maybe humans just in the back monitoring things at the place. You can walk out with items with human interaction but the problem with initial platform is that when the store is getting too crowded in a prolonged time, it can no longer monitor what the customer has picked up. They say -- we will keep an eye on the business that's at stake.

There is also talk of new stores that may not be exactly Whole Foods, you know, and new brands as well, that may be less price because the stocks are trying to shed that Whole Foods, whole paycheck image and trying to make it ready for everybody. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Nicole Petallides, thank you so much. We will watch that. We'll take a short break. When we come back, final thoughts from our all-star panel.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Final thoughts from our all-stars. Heather.

ZUMARRAGA: A big week ahead we got rate hikes, Sessions testimony may be in public or private and big tech names to watch.

BARTIROMO: Buckle up, that's what you're saying.

ZUMARRAGA: Buckle up.

BARTIROMO: James Freeman.

FREEMAN: I'm watching the text docs too, I also want to say happy anniversary mom and dad Steve and Gloria Block.

BARTIROMO: How many years?

FREEMAN: A lot.

FREEMAN: Bad son. But he did wish you a happy anniversary on air.

ZUMARRAGA: The federal reserve is set to raise quarter basis points again on Wednesday, I'm more interested to see if they hint that unwinding their balance sheet and reducing some a little the liquidity that helps prop the markets up.

BARTIROMO: That we probably won't find out until the fall I think Septembers the application for that.

ZUMARRAGA: Maybe.

BARTIROMO: Thanks to Heather and James, see you all. All right, we will leave it there and we'll see you tomorrow with another big show. As request "VARNEY & COMPANY" is on deck. Stu, take it away.

830

END

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D3PM-00000-00Profit from Experience; Airlines Eye the Heat; Daisy Carnival Heats Up; Georgia Heads to the Polls; South Carolina Elections;2017-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisProfit from Experience; Airlines Eye the Heat; Daisy Carnival Heats Up; Georgia Heads to the Polls; South Carolina Elections;LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Tuesday, June 20th. Here are your top stories 6:00 A.M. on the East Coast.

President Trump takes aim at North Korea after Otto Warmbier dies days after returning to the United States with severe brain damage. The company that took into the country now saying it will no longer take Americans there. It says a tragedy like this should never be repeated.

Meanwhile on Capitol Hill, a push for reform this morning. "The Wall Street Journal" reporting a health care vote will take place next week. The administration holding firm that tax reform will also get done this year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. SECRETARY OF TREASURY: I have no higher priority than having tax reform done this year. We're working every day. We're working with the house and the senate. We're committed to get this done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Plus, a contentious moment between Senators Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer coming up.

It is technically not even summer. But the southwest is facing a dangerous heat wave this morning. Temperatures already near triple digits today. We will give you the latest.

And the heat taking a toll. American Airlines has cancelled more than a dozen flights. More than 1,000 needed medical attention at the Electric Daisy Concert in Las Vegas.

Markets look like this this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating a mixed opening for the broader averages. Fractionally better on the session. The Dow and the S&P coming up of a record close yesterday. Looking to extend that today with fractional moves in the upside. Dow Industrial sets to open up about 10 points. Ditto for the NASDAQ.

In Europe, the indices look like this. Take a look. European indices higher across the board with the CAC quarante in Paris, best performer up about a third of a percent.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower, meanwhile. Take a look. As you see the best performer was the Nikkei in Japan that was up one percent. The others down fractionally.

Tom Brady wants to play an NFL game outside of the U.S. We will reveal where he says is his dream country to play one day. All those stories coming up this morning.

And joining me to talk about it, financial analyst Heather Zumarraga is with us. Wall Street Journal assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman is with us. And the London Center for Policy Research, Vice President Lieutenant Colonel Tony Shaffer is here. Great to see you.

TONY SHAFFER, LONDON CENTER FOR POLICY RESEARCH: Great seeing you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: What's on top this morning, James? What do you think of the big stories?

FREEMAN: Well, at long last, patients, doctors, taxpayers may finally see the beginning of the end of ObamaCare.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. They were looking for a vote next week. So we'll see that. We will talk about all of that this morning.

Coming up joining the conversation, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross is with us today. Tennessee Congresswoman Marsha Blackburn is with us today. Fox News Military analyst, Jack Keane is here. Harvard law professor emeritus Alan Dershowitz is here. And former Raegan campaign advisor, Ed Rollins is here as well. You don't want to miss moments of it. So just stay with us throughout the show.

We kick it off this hour right now with Otto Warmbier. The American student imprisoned in North Korea for 17 months and sent back to the United States in a persistent vegetative state last week, died yesterday. He died at the tender age of 22 years old. Doctors treating the University of Virginia student said late last week that Warmbier had extensive loss of brain tissue and he was in the state of unresponsive wakefulness.

Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in North Korea for allegedly stealing a propaganda poster during an organized tour to the isolated country. The Chinese company behind Young Pioneer Tours, the tour company that sent him there now says it will stop taking U.S. citizens to North Korea.

President Trump weighed in on the sad news from the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D3PK-00000-00Profit from Experience; Airlines Eye the Heat; Daisy Carnival Heats Up; Georgia Heads to the Polls; South Carolina Elections;2017-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisProfit from Experience; Airlines Eye the Heat; Daisy Carnival Heats Up; Georgia Heads to the Polls; South Carolina Elections;LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Tuesday, June 20th. Here are your top stories 6:00 A.M. on the East Coast.

President Trump takes aim at North Korea after Otto Warmbier dies days after returning to the United States with severe brain damage. The company that took into the country now saying it will no longer take Americans there. It says a tragedy like this should never be repeated.

Meanwhile on Capitol Hill, a push for reform this morning. "The Wall Street Journal" reporting a health care vote will take place next week. The administration holding firm that tax reform will also get done this year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. SECRETARY OF TREASURY: I have no higher priority than having tax reform done this year. We're working every day. We're working with the house and the senate. We're committed to get this done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Plus, a contentious moment between Senators Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer coming up.

It is technically not even summer. But the southwest is facing a dangerous heat wave this morning. Temperatures already near triple digits today. We will give you the latest.

And the heat taking a toll. American Airlines has cancelled more than a dozen flights. More than 1,000 needed medical attention at the Electric Daisy Concert in Las Vegas.

Markets look like this this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating a mixed opening for the broader averages. Fractionally better on the session. The Dow and the S&P coming up of a record close yesterday. Looking to extend that today with fractional moves in the upside. Dow Industrial sets to open up about 10 points. Ditto for the NASDAQ.

In Europe, the indices look like this. Take a look. European indices higher across the board with the CAC quarante in Paris, best performer up about a third of a percent.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower, meanwhile. Take a look. As you see the best performer was the Nikkei in Japan that was up one percent. The others down fractionally.

Tom Brady wants to play an NFL game outside of the U.S. We will reveal where he says is his dream country to play one day. All those stories coming up this morning.

And joining me to talk about it, financial analyst Heather Zumarraga is with us. Wall Street Journal assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman is with us. And the London Center for Policy Research, Vice President Lieutenant Colonel Tony Shaffer is here. Great to see you.

TONY SHAFFER, LONDON CENTER FOR POLICY RESEARCH: Great seeing you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: What's on top this morning, James? What do you think of the big stories?

FREEMAN: Well, at long last, patients, doctors, taxpayers may finally see the beginning of the end of ObamaCare.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. They were looking for a vote next week. So we'll see that. We will talk about all of that this morning.

Coming up joining the conversation, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross is with us today. Tennessee Congresswoman Marsha Blackburn is with us today. Fox News Military analyst, Jack Keane is here. Harvard law professor emeritus Alan Dershowitz is here. And former Raegan campaign advisor, Ed Rollins is here as well. You don't want to miss moments of it. So just stay with us throughout the show.

We kick it off this hour right now with Otto Warmbier. The American student imprisoned in North Korea for 17 months and sent back to the United States in a persistent vegetative state last week, died yesterday. He died at the tender age of 22 years old. Doctors treating the University of Virginia student said late last week that Warmbier had extensive loss of brain tissue and he was in the state of unresponsive wakefulness.

Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in North Korea for allegedly stealing a propaganda poster during an organized tour to the isolated country. The Chinese company behind Young Pioneer Tours, the tour company that sent him there now says it will stop taking U.S. citizens to North Korea.

President Trump weighed in on the sad news from the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Otto Warmbier has just passed away. He spent a year and a half in North Korea. A lot of bad things happened. But at least we got him home to be with his parents where they were so happy to see him, even though he was in very tough condition.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Warmbier's parents Fred and Cindy put the blame squarely at North Korea writing in a statement, "Unfortunately the awful torturous mistreatment our son received at the hands of the North Koreans ensure that no other outcome was possible beyond the sad one we experienced today.

Tony, your take on these developments.

SHAFFER: Well, look, there's no doubt in my mind he was tortured. Let's be very clear what happened here. And I've already said another interviews I think there needs to be some level of retaliation. I'll just be that direct about it. My son is 23. I cannot imagine the pain these parents are going through. This is truly tragic.

My understanding from talking to the experts, he was tortured not so much the way where you'd be pulling fingernails out with tools, but by repeated drugging, sodium pentothal. The idea was they were trying to figure out if he was a CIA spy or not. He wasn't. And the continued and repeated exposure over that year to these drugs is what caused the consistent and persistent damage of the entire brain. So it was essentially the use of these drugs over and over again which caused the brain damage.

BARTIROMO: Now, there were some reports that he went into the vegetative state just recently, a couple of weeks ago. So, was that --

SHAFER: I don't buy that. I think this --

BARTIROMO: The whole time you think he was just drugged?

SHAFFER: I think they started during his confinement and did it over and over. And I think of the reasons they released him --I mean no doubt, President Trump saw this and started dealing with it early on. But no doubt they kind of like saw that some things are going to go tragically wrong. We better get this guy out of here, anyway. So let's serve their purpose to get him out.

The parents got their boy back, their son back. But again, Maria, it does not change the fact that he was tortured. This is something that we should not stand for. And I believe that President Trump recognizes how hideous this is and something requires a response.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And what kind of response do you expect? Should be warranted.

SHAFFER: We in the Cold War, we had organizations which focused on is what they called dirty tricks in the old days. Look, we need to rethink our foreign policy. We cannot simply sit back and let dictators, horrible people like Kim Jong-un do these things and think they can get away with it. There's been no push back. This is a remote analogy. But we just shut down a certain aircraft. We haven't shut down an aircraft since 1999. So I think it's time we re-insinuate ourselves in foreign policy in a way that the -- those bad guys like Un understand there's going to be consequences for bad behavior. There's been no bad consequences for decades.

BARTIROMO: And Otto's parents said that. Look, President Obama told us to be quite. President Trump took our son home. James, how do you see it?

FREEMAN: Well, this is one of the last to the old style dictatorships. This is what communists, dictatorships so. I think it was probably surprising to a lot of people over the last year following this news that you actually tend to travel to North Korea. To this point, the state department has a -- had a strong warning and I think maybe you'd expect from now it would be something more like a -- like a band -- I mean, obviously they don't treat visitors any better than they treat their own people. And this -- for anyone who didn't realize that, yes, this is a wake up call.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, FINANCIAL ANALYST: But so maybe we should it be there though. There are some -- to some extent, we shouldn't be going to these places.

BARTIROMO: But this was a tour company from China, Heather. I mean, if you've got a tour company, you may be thinking that you're OK and that you're with a safe group.

Let's switch gears to the standoff in the senate right now. Because this is also a piece of important business today. Republicans are aiming for a vote on the health care bill next week. A full week ahead of the July 4th recess since the democrats have begun using parliamentary maneuvers to slow down business in the chamber though to protest any bill including a series of back to back speeches on the floor yesterday.

In one exchange, minority leader Chuck Schumer press his counterpart, Mitch McConnell to commit to an open debate. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), MINORITY LEADER: When we have time more than 10 hours, since this is a complicated bill to review the bill, will it be available to us and the public, more than 10 hours before we have to vote for it.

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), MAJORITY LEADER: I think we'll have an ample opportunity to read and amend the bill.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Do you see republicans pushing through to get this done before July 4th, James Freeman? And also, what's your take on this ostracism? They're basically telling you in advance. Look, we're going to do long speeches. We're going to do whatever it takes to waste time so this doesn't get done?

FREEMAN: Yes. So a lot of theatrics. I think the republicans will get it done. It's interesting there. You look at Chuck Schumer saying, I want 10 hours to read bill. Of course, if you took another clip from that speech he was saying, as he often does that this is a terrible bill and he's opposed to it. So he's not -- he's not an over minded voter here looking to consider the measure. He doesn't need 10 hours. He's already against it without even having seen it because this is the Obama legacy project, no matter how bad it's failing. They have tied themselves to it politically and they're going to do well of the parliamentary moves they can do to slow it down but they can't and it'll pass.

BARTIROMO: Is there any chance though that they are able to stop any business whatsoever that the Trump administration trust to put forth? That's the whole plan. Let his president be a president that gets nothing done. Let this congress be get nothing done congress that we take the house in '18 and we impeach him in '20?

FREEMAN: I don't think that will work. Because if you basically make it impossible to do business, what they're going to do is they're going to kill the legislative filibuster which still exists and allows them to block things like -- any measure that can't get 60 votes. Now, health care is different because they're going through this recompilation process. But basically if they put up a big roadblock like they did with Gorsuch, it' going to hurt their agenda because they're not going to be able to stop anything else. It seems a lot of republicans are going to say, enough. We're going to filibuster.

BARTIROMO: All right. So then you do think a health care vote happens?

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let me ask you about House Speaker Paul Ryan. He sets to deliver his first major speech on tax reform today. According to the excerpts of the speech that have been released, he's expected to urge republicans, "We need to get his done in 2017. We cannot let this once in a generation moment slip."

Now, Heather, if we don't see tax reform, big implications from markets?

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, the markets have been up hitting all-time highs. Yet again, I think Futures are up today. We'll see if the Dow can hit new highs today. It's tax reform. It's health care. That's what it's all about. That's what the markets are running on right now.

BARTIROMO: James, what do you want to hear from Paul Ryan today?

FREEMAN: I'd like to hear him say that the number one priority is growing this economy.

BARTIROMO: That's what he's going to say. You know that.

FREEMAN: Well, I'm worried that he's also going to say that this has got to be revenue natural. We've got to stick with the conventions of beltway score keeping no matter how flawed they are.

BARTIROMO: Right. And that means the border adjustment tax or higher corporate rate or some kind of a revenue, right?

FREEMAN: They've got to get the corporate rate into the teams if we want a real game changer.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Tony?

SHAFFER: Look, I think what we've seen over and over again is reluctant facts to actually break out of what we know doesn't work. The scoring system, we know doesn't work, doesn't matter. The democrats always refer to it. And what I don't understand why the republicans haven't gone back and looked at the numbers that CBO did on the original estimates for ObamaCare and look at how wildly of they were. So it's kind of like how is that you don't just look at what bad work they did and say throw it out because it doesn't work.

BARTIROMO: You're right. It's funny to hear Chuck Schumer say, well, when you do things in the dark of night. Excuse me, ObamaCare was done in the dark of night.

ZUMARRAGA: No. Find out what's in the bill after we pass the bill.

BARTIROMO: Nancy Pelosi. We have the Trump tweets to tell you about the president is tweeting this morning. And we want to bring you to you right now President Trump just tweeting about the Georgia special election. "Democrat Jon Ossoff who wants to raise your taxes to the highest level and is weak on crime and security doesn't even live in the district. Karen Handel for congress, she will fight for lower taxes, great health care, strong security. A hard worker who will never give up. Vote today.

We've got more analysis on this. The special election happening in Georgia. Of course it's real important. It's the most money, right? In the congressional election.

FREEMAN: Ossoff has raised more than 23 million bucks. He's got about five times the money that Karen Handel has. He's raising his money basically outside of Georgia. So it's going to be a question of whether people want to -- Georgia voters want to allow the rest of the country's liberals to use them as a vehicle to oppose the president.

BARTIROMO: Does this tell us anything, I mean, if Ossoff wins or Handel wins, does this tell us anything about the republican party or democratic party today do you think? Is this going to be sort of an indicator?

SHAFFER: Well, Georgia has been one of the states that the democrats have been trying to turn for a while. I mean, there was during the last election cycle, I believe, which was not founded on anything real that they could turn this state blue and they didn't. But I think you see over and over again, every election, we've seen special cycle election, outside money's been donated heavily and they've lost every time. And I think it's going to happen again here because the overwhelming feeling still is that I think people want to give President Trump time to get his act together. I think this is a microcosm of other things. And Georgia still I think is more red than blue.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. We'll take a short break. We have a lot more on the congressional race today.

But first, let's take a break. A heat wave is striking the southwest. The national weather service predicting highs of 120 degrees today with some states already having canceled flights to the region. We're on it next. Stay with us. Quick break.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A brutal heat wave hitting the southwest United States. Cheryl Casone with the story now. Cheryl, good morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, good morning, Maria. OK. Temperatures could reach 120 degrees today in parts of Arizona for the first time in more than 20 years. This is a record-breaking 122 that happened back in 1990. Also, the city of Las Vegas and southern California bracing for what authorities are calling a public health hazard. Death Valley could reach temperatures as high as 124 degrees.

Airlines also watching the weather, at least -- excuse me, 20 American Airlines flights out of Arizona have already been cancelled because those planes can't operate over a temperature of 118. That's according to a statement from the airline. It's the smaller aircraft. Americans saying that flight changes are going to be free of charge for passengers.

Meanwhile, one person is dead and nearly 1,000 needed medical attention on site at the Electric Daisy Carnival in Las Vegas. Sixteen other people taken to a local hospital. According to -- still can't determine the cause of death for 34-year-old Michael Morse. He passed away after attending the festival on Saturday. The heat though could have been a factor. The temperature in Las Vegas reach 110 degrees. He experienced convulsions about 3:23 in the morning. According to police there, a total of 340 medical calls were handled on Saturday.

And you were just talking about this, Maria. Over 140,000 ballots have already been cast in the Georgia congressional race for democrat John Ossoff is looking to defeat Karen Handel. Ossoff raising, a record setting 15 million. President Trump tweeting on the election just saying this, big day tomorrow in Georgia and South Carolina. ObamaCare is dead. Dems wants to raise taxes big. They can only obstruct. No ideas vote "R." And this coming as a new ad pack - ad paid for by PAC supporting Handel is receiving backlash for showing images of House Majority Whip Scalise after he was shot in a baseball game last week. The spokesperson for Handel condemning that act saying, "For any group to use the shootings this week for political or personal benefit is shameful. This group should be ashamed."

Meanwhile, South Carolina also holding elections. Democrat Archie Parnell faces republican Paul Norman to replace Mick Mulvaney. And of course the president tapped to be budget director. That election is going to test if the republican candidate can gain support from largely African-American districts, Maria. So a lot going on politically today. Those were your headlines.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl. Thanks so much. Coming up next, record closing for the Dow and the S&P 500 yesterday. Technology stops once again rebounding and leading this market high. We're taking a closer look at markets and the best performers, next.

Then play a game, win a job. Jaguar L, Land Rover's new technique for recruiting engineers straight ahead. Stay with us right here "Mornings with Maria." After this.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Stocks looking to extend yesterday's record run. The gains driven by the technology sector yesterday. Of course, tech has been down and now it looks like it's stabilizing a bit in recent weeks.

Joining us right now is GFI Group chief macro strategist, John Spallanzani. John good to see you.

JOHN SPALLANZANI, CHIEF MACRO STRATEGIST, GFI GROUP: Good seeing you.

BARTIROMO: What's going on in markets right now? Is money coming back into technology after the Amazon announcement of the Whole Foods?

SPALLANZANI: I think we saw some rotation out of tech and into some of the big financial names. Hopefully that they're expecting some tax relief. Obviously a steeper occur because the Fed hike rates. I think that we see small caps catching a bit again. Those have been flat for a while, for six months. We've been consolidating all those stocks that run up after the election kind of went sideways and now we're starting to see some rotations which is healthy in the market.

The NASDAQ is up 16 percent. The S&P is almost up 10 percent now. So we saw a lot of momentum into, again, the dime and so there was a bit divergence between tech last week was down like 150 basis points. But yet, the diamonds were up 180 basis points. So those are three percent swing in one week where guys obviously rotating out of tech and then for someone bigger names.

BARTIROMO: And then bigger names and you say diamond. Bigger names --

SPALLANZANI: The Dow stocks and also the S&P stocks. People are expecting the effective tax rates and corporations to go down. So those corporations with the highest effective tax rates right now are being targeted because they're going to get the biggest boost if we do get some taxes.

BARTIROMO: targeted to buy. So Wall Street still believes in tax reform in '17 is what you're saying?

SPALLANZANI: I think the media is more interested in '17 and '18. I think right now we're just worried about the message. But the message is good right now. And I think that whether it's '17 or '18, there's other good things. Earnings are obviously very good. I don't think -- we didn't see -- this rally is not based on multiple expansions. It's really based on earnings so far.

So if you look at stock multiples compared to credit and bonds, stocks are still cheap relative to the other two. So, where else are you going to put your money?

FREEMAN: OK. But they are still expensive relative to their earnings historically -- that's a hard metric to pin down. Because -- OK. Let's say they're not relative to their earnings. Here's on the upper level. Here's where I'm wondering is how much of this is company's doing well, how much is the optimism surrounding Trump and reform and how much is still very loose monetary policy around the world? We're -- in the U.S. kind of taking baby steps toward going back to normal. But in central banks, they printed a lot of money.

ZUMARRAGA: Last week, even though we raised, a lot of people are point out that the central banks around the world, including Europe and Japan are still easing at a rate of $1 trillion, so global central banks are still easing although we're increasing rates in the U.S.

SPALLANZANI: Yes. There's still a lot of capital around. I think the other reason why our yield curve is so flat because, again, treasuries are tier one capital that everybody has not the balance sheets. There's no alternative to treasuries, really. So, do you want to invest in goes to 27 basis points? Which is like last night. What do you want it by treasury 220? That's the trade. So there's not a lot of alternatives to what you have going on. So that's another thing that's keeping rates down that's helping.

Just last night, just this morning, Carney said, I'm not going to tight in -- the Bank of England is not going to tie because he fears that we have still on present talks, want to go slow. Les Evans. Last night again that listen, we're not going to tight in -- we might not tight in September, maybe December because inflation is still undershooting the Feds.

BARTIROMO: Right. So the Fed is still a major factor here, is what you're saying. And Easy money around the world.

Let me ask you, what would you do right now? Do you want to put money into this market here knowing that maybe health care reform gets done next week? I mean, the health care bill rather, the vote. And then tax reform later in the year. And then what about Europe?

SPALLANZANI: I think steady as she goes. I mean, it's evitable for quite a long time. I still think that we're at 2,500 now. Have a few bets, personal bets to - we might hit 2,700 by the end of the year.

BARTIROMO: On the S&P 500.

SPALLANZANI: In the S&P 500. Yup. That's a big -- it's a big move from here. But it's still June and there's so much left that we could do and especially if the Fed does not hike in September, there's not a lot of resistance above.

I think right now, when I'm watching, is the unemployment rate next in July rate. If we start to see that tick higher then I would get more concerned. Right now, unemployment is obviously very low. And also wages are kind of not so hot.

BARTIROMO: No. Stagnant.

SHAFFER: I have a quick question on Brexit. We had one year anniversary couple days ago. They're starting to make their negotiations. How do you see your stocks worth rolling as a negotiation starts?

SPALLANZANI: European stocks have been actually performing better than -- that's my marker right now.

BARTIROMO: With the easy money there, yes.

SPALLANZANI: Yes, the easy money. But I think that May has got problems, right? So we see that the more problems May has, the higher the market goes in Europe, right? So that meeting that Brexit is not going to be a hard Brexit. So I think new markets going to discounting that.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Oil price is down. Okay.

SPALLANZANI: Who would have thought that oil via 44 and the stocks be at 2,500. So oil is a technology driven story, not a supply story and not a recessionary story. That's a huge positive oil being a 44.

BARTIROMO: Okay. A technology story?

SPALLANZANI: Fracking and the ability for the U.S. to be one of the biggest exporters in the world and that's really Trump's

BARTIROMO: John, great to see you. Thank you so much. John Spallanzani joining us there.

Coming up, police reportedly identified the man suspected of plowing his van into a crowded London. 47-year-old, Darren Osborne is arrested by authorities on suspicion of terrorist offences.

And then technology giants headed to Washington. I'll speak with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross about President Trump's meeting yesterday with Silicon Valley CEOs. Back in a moment. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
