Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKV-7161-JDPT-T1YN-00000-00Progressive Policy Institute Holds Discussion on Blockchain Issues2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisProgressive Policy Institute Holds Discussion on Blockchain Issues

Progressive Policy Institute Holds Discussion On Blockchain Issues

July 16, 2019 12:00 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

REP. DARREN SOTO (D-FLA.)

SONECON LLC CHAIRMAN ROB SHAPIRO

MEDICI VENTURES PRESIDENT JONATHAN JOHNSON

VOATZ DIRECTOR OF PRODUCT HILLARY BRASETH TZERO CHIEF LEGAL OFFICER ALAN KONEVSKY

VOATZ CEO NIMIT SAWHNEY

CONGRESSMAN SOTO FINANCIAL AND TECHNOLOGY POLICY ADVISOR BILL ROCKWOOD

PROGRESSIVE POLICY INSTITUTE PRESIDENT WILL MARSHALL

MEDICI LAND GOVERNANCE PRINCIPAL SOFTWARE DEVELOPER TRENT LARSON

[*]MARSHALL: Good afternoon, everybody. My name is Will Marshall, I'm president of the Progressive Policy Institute and I want to welcome you today to this Capitol Hill Forum on Blockchain 101: Harnessing the Distributed Power Blockchain Technology. Thanks we--we've had great interest in this and a lot of people signed up and we really appreciate your coming out today to learn more about this fascinating subject.

Progressive Policy Institute, if you all know us, know that we have made a study of digital innovation and its impact on economic investment and job creation in America a centerpiece of the work that--that we do. We think it is the absolute driver of our economy and the key to our ability to win the race for economic privacy with--with China.

And blockchain is on the, you know, sort of an exciting new frontier of digital innovation but its revolutionary potential is not well understood here in Washington, I think. I--I will confess to be, you know, as a late adopter of technology someone who needs to learn more but I think that's--a lot of people up here do.

We all know it has something to do with bitcoin but after that it gets pretty--pretty murky. But, you know, blockchain technology is emerging as a kind of general purpose technology for all sorts of data sharing applications and transactions and we are very fortunate today to have a wonderful crew of blockchain entrepreneurs here who are pio--pioneering fascinating new applications for this technology and we're going to hear from them about what they're doing and, I hope to learn a little more about how the--the technology actually works and Rob Shapiro is going to--is going to lead that conversation in just a minute. But before--before we get there, I just want to say this, there's kind of a lucky accident of timing that we're here talking about blockchain when Congress is hauling in the big tech--tech companies, you know, for inquest this week and basically raising questions about the market power of these tech giants and--and there's a lot of concern about that and--and I wonder, and I'll just put this as a question, but you know, to--to some extent, is blockchain technology an answer to this techlash, this concern about centralization of power and of the--the monopolistic role of--of big platforms by enabling decentralized networks and lowering the number of intermediaries and reducing transaction costs and creating higher levels of data security.

Blockchain can, perhaps, organize innovation ecosystems and commerce in ways that--that doesn't seed enormous market power to platform operators and avoids some of the pitfalls that we're going to hear about this week in the other hearings and it raises, obviously, a whole lot of important public policy implications that we're going to explore today too, if we have time.

So without further ado, we--Representative Darren Sutten--Soto, of--of Florida was supposed to be here. Unfortunately, he went to the doctor this morning and was diagnosed with some kind of flu or contagion and mercifully decided not to come and be with us. That's too bad, but we are fortunate to have pinch-hitting Bill Rockwood, who is Congressman Soto's Financial and Tec--Tech Policy Advisor. And, of course, Congressman Soto is the Co-Chair of the Congressional Blockchain Caucus. So, it would be good to get your perspective on what's happening with the caucus and--and--and Congress on--on this subject. So, Bill, over to you.

ROCKWOOD: Well, first, thank you for the great introduction. You did a fantastic job queuing up a lot of the issues that are to come. Again, my name is Bill Rockwood. I apologize, my boss, Darren Soto, couldn't be here today; it's probably in our own best interest he isn't, but happy for this opportunity and this gathering.

I've actually been trying to put together an event myself entitled: Blockchain for Dems and I will make the disclaimer, let's try to leave bitcoin and--and Facebook at the door today because I think that's what get--gets a lot of attention. Frankly, it's why Republicans might be a little further along on this issue. But I think this is a great panel and there is a really strong opportunity for--for Dems and the Progressive Caucus to take a lead, because if you project five, ten years down the road, a lot of the blockchain technologies and the way it works, plays very well into the Democratic platform. So I'm happy to engage further with any of you all behind the scenes but just mention some things like reducing healthcare costs, cyber security in elections, food tracing, tracking humanitarian aid dollars. Like all of these things become more efficient and open and transparent because of the way the technology works.

So, yes, bitcoin and--and the Facebook Libra thing are major things these days, but I see all of this as a way to get to the more interesting discussion, which is blockchain itself and just to--those are some areas and--and just, we won't go into the 101. Hopefully our panelists will go into that, but just to throw some provocative things out there, it's a way to reduce energy consumption, increase cyber security and your us--user privacy than traditional networks.

Again, Mr. Soto is a Co-Chair of the Congressional Blockchain Caucus and in that role, the caucus really sees itself as an educational outlet. Yes, we are trying to coordinate groups like this and have done a lot of different subjects, but this is a new issue so there are a lot of questions and, you know, whether it's getting beyond bitcoin to blockchain, and a lot of times it's just coming in, and my biggest role this year I've realized is flipping the discussion. It's--my job isn't to explain blockchain to you, like there's always going to be an inherent difficulty and bandwidth issue with some of those, but if you come to me with issues your boss cares about, I can find an application and ways that we can work together.

So use this as a good introductory 101 on like how the technology works at a high level, but really thinking through the implications as a way to make a name for yourself like I did as a staffer. No one's touching this on the Dems side. So, I issue that challenge to you, you know, I don't want to be out here by myself all the time on this stuff--

(LAUGHTER)

But really, as a young staffer, it's the quickest way to make an impact and a different--difference for your boss. The caucus emphasizes a light touch regulatory approach and I guarantee, we can find a project for everyone in here to work on it, if--if you're motivated. So I'll leave my--my cards on the outside and feel free to get in touch.

Just some specifics in terms of what Mr. Soto probably would have talked about, we have introduced some legislation to help with the jurisdiction of--to clarify what different digital assets, again, that goes down the bitcoin/Facebook route but happy to chat about that. And, with the appropriations and things like the NDAA, there are such profound implications. Like we got eight pieces of legislative report language in, the most recent appropriations process related to crypto and blockchain. So, again, I--I pose this out to the--the next generation of staffers, you know, how this is going to be a--a $30, I think, billion dollar industry in 2030. It's coming. I think it has the potential to be the next Silicon Valley, so, again, we want to make sure this occurs domestically but it's also a great way to get yourselves involved in an issue that is going to effect the future. You know, that's why, in theory, we--we do this job to make a difference, get involved and by--by getting in front of policy issues you can really make a big im--impact for both your boss and the future that's to come.

So thank you for this opportunity and I look forward to the panel discussion.

MARSHALL: Thank you. Thanks very much, Bill, I'm sorry to hear that blockchain people are so lonely here on Capitol Hill--Maytag repairman. I'm not going to give Rob Shapiro the--the lavish introduction he--he deserves. But, Rob, is really the moving spirit of this--of this event today and I want to thank him for focusing us at PPI on blockchain technology. Rob is the founder and chairman of Sonecon, he's really one of the foremost economic thinkers and analyst in America. He was the Undersecretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs under Bill Clinton and he oversaw the Bureau of Economic Analysis and the Census Bureau. Aren't you glad you don't have that job now, Rob?

But, he's been an advisor to every Democratic president since and just one of the sharpest economists, economic thinkers, that we have here and we're fortunate to count him as a friend and as a former PPI colleague; somebody present at the creation of PPI many years ago. So without further ado, Rob, over to you and--and to hear from our entrepreneurs is really--what--what we're going to really learn today. Thanks.

SHAPIRO: Thanks for coming. I--I just want to say this is, in PPI's tradition of always being on the cutting edge of policy. And so I really want to thank Will. I'm going to talk for less than a minute and then we'll hear from the people who are building companies and new operations around blockchain.

Many of you know, it's the technology behind bitcoin. The way to think about it is that bitcoin is to blockchain what email was to the internet. It's the first killer app. Think of where the internet was in 1990 or 1992; that's where blockchain is today. I personally think it will be a $30 billion industry by 2022, not by 2030, and growing very, very fast after that. So the question is, why are Bill Gates, Wall Street and Silicon Valley so interested in blockchain today? It's a peer-to-peer network or a person-to-person network, as Jonathan Johnson puts it, for nearly any transaction.

Today most of us use some trusted middleman like a bank or a credit card company to make a transaction and we pay fees to do it. Blockchain allows everyone to carry out many transactions directly removing the cost and inefficiency of a third-party. This is a radically efficient technology which is why, as it--as its capacity grows, it--it will, economically, has to become pervasive. I--I'm not going to describe how, exactly how, it works, I'm going to leave that to the--the panel but the fact is that blockchain works with any type of transaction involving value; whether it's money or goods or property. Governments can use it to collect taxes, for example.

Moreover, its potential uses go beyond that because the assets and money being transferred through a blockchain are just digital information made very secure between one party or another. So blockchain can do the same with any type of digital information. For example, voting, or land titles.

We have with us today people who can talk on all of these topics. We have--I'm going to introduce them very briefly right now and then we'll go to the questioning. Jonathon Johnson, the chairman of Medici Ventures which is the leading blockchain incubator and venturer (PH) investor in America. Hillary Braseth is the director of Product for Voatz which is the leading actor in blockchain-based voting for elections. Trent Larson, is the Principal Software Developer for Medici Land Governance which is the leading blockchain-based land titling venture in the world and Al--Al--Alan Konevsky is the Chief Legal Officer for tZERO which is the--the leading player in America in developing blockchain-based capital markets. So, we're touching a lot of areas.

I'm going to start with Jonathan Johnson. Jonathan, tell us why you think blockchain is so promising and so important?

JOHNSON: Well, Rob, thank you and, Will, thank you for hosting this, this is just fantastic. I want to go back to the analogy that Rob used to talk about the internet. When the internet first came on the scene, we used to refer to it as the information superhighway and that's because it made the transfer of information nearly free and nearly frictionless and that's transformed the--the world that we live in.

When we use the internet to transfer something, we give a copy. So if you send an email or a picture or a Website, you're serving up a copy of something to somebody. And no one cares that you get a copy of my picture or my email, but if I'm giving you an asset, you don't want a copy of my asset; mostly because you don't want me spending it twice, three times, end (PH) times.

Blockchain is really the digital assets superhighway. It lets you and I transfer goods electronically just like we transfer information electronically and--and--and Rob said that email is to the internet what bitcoin is to blockchain. It's the first killer app. It's the first asset that used blockchain technology but, assets include things like your vote, once you give it, you don't (PH) want to be able to cast it again and again and again in the same election. They include things like land, hard assets that we can digitize. They include things like stock certificates that today, when we transfer these things, we have a bunch of people in between; real estate brokers, title insurance people, brokers, prime brokers, clearing agents, county clerks; all these people in between us to make sure that when we transfer something we can trust each other.

Blockchain is the digital trust agent. It's almost like, when I was a kid I liked to trade baseball cards. My neighbor down the street, (INAUDIBLE) was a Cincinnati Red's fan, I was a Dodgers fan. When we would get each other's cards that we wanted, we each hold one half of the card that we were trading and on the count of one, two, three, we'd let go--thank you--we'd let go and pull. Well, that was kind of a handshake of sorts. Blockchain technology is the digital handshake that lets us each hold part of an asset; my money, Alan's stock, and one, two, three, without someone in the middle, let go and pull. That's why I think it's so revolutionary.

SHAPIRO: And what is it that keeps it secure?

JOHNSON: Well, when you think about why we use trust agents, it's because they--we are relying on them to keep it secure. We're relying on Equifax to keep our information secure. We're relying on banks to keep our information secure. Blockchain technology is two things; principally they keep it secure; one is the cryptography that has the information that's in it cryptographically secure and then the fact that there's no one single ledger that if a hacker hacks into, like Equifax, or your bank, they can figure out everything they need to know about you and have everything that you have. This is a distributed ledger so that all five of us up here have a ledger and if you hack into mine, you can't deplete what I own because all the other four of us haven't been hacked into and they represent the truth and the one hacked ledger gets fixed that way.

That's--that's my non-technical explanation. Transit technologist; I'm not.

SHAPIRO: Right. Think of a block on the blockchain as a network of computers and for any exchange to occur, they all have to approve it. They all have a record of the asset that's being transferred and so it all has to concur. So, as Jonathan said, you hack into one and you cannot get a hold of that asset; it's the whole network.

Since we're on Capitol Hill, let's turn to blockchain technologies application to elections. Hillary, you're from Voatz, the leading company in blockchain-based voting right now, how--how does Voatz use blockchain to make voting secure and efficient?

BRASETH: Sure, thank you so much. And thank you, Jonathan, that was a really wonderful way to, I think, bring down to earth this core concept of what is blockchain? Can you all hear me? Okay. So I work with Voatz and Voatz is a mobile voting system backed by blockchain technology. So, the way that we use blockchain is the final step of the voting process. So, if you are a voter and you decide to use Voatz in an election or your jurisdiction allows you to vote with Voatz, your experience of this would be using the device that all of you carry around in your hand or your pocket and what you would do is you would download the Voatz app, sign up for an account and you would go through an identity verification process where you would take a picture of your photo ID, take a live selfie of your face, so you blink up and down, look sideways to make sure you're not taking a picture of another picture, or a picture of a video and that identity verification process simultaneously checks against the states Voter Registration database to ensure that you are, indeed, a voter.

So, yes, we do require a government issued photo ID which is a tradeoff if you want to use the convenience of voting. This wouldn't replace you being able to still show up at the poll without an ID and--and vote that way.

Once that process is complete, you're instantly pinged with your mobile ballot, mobile pic (PH). So you make your selections and in the background what's happening, every single oval that you're filling in on your ballot equals essentially what we call a vote transaction on the blockchain. So, when you make all of your selections, and at the moment that you press submit, which uses your biometrics which are already tied to your identity, that ballot passes through the blockchain and this is where it becomes very compelling because rather than being validated by one single server and stored on one single server, it goes through a validation process that passes through all of the different validators participating in the network to ensure that what you voted for, is indeed what's logged as an aggregate count of the vote. And that's how we use blockchain is to secure that aggregate count so that in the event that somebody tried to be nefarious in our--in our elections, we would have a sustained record of who won the election. Whereas, right now, our trust is all placed in, well, I guess it's the media these days that announces who wins--

(LAUGHTER)

--an election, or the, you know, governing body that's hosting the election.

SHAPIRO: You know, there have been a lot of elections where the final result is held up because they're waiting for the overseas vote and the military vote. How does--how does Voatz simplify that process?

BRASETH: Yeah, thank you. So, essentially we've been around for about three years and we've run all types of elections from university voting to local towns, non-profits. We've had a lot of headway this past year with that very population; overseas voters, which are classified as what we call UOCAVA voters. There's about three million overseas U.S. citizens and right now their only options to vote include postal mail, fax and email. Now, I lived in West Africa for three years and I didn't vote once because there's no postal system in Guinea. So, this population, their average voter turnout is 7 percent which is, by and large, one of the most disenfranchised voting blocks that we have in our country.

So, this past fall we piloted with the State of West Virginia and allowed overseas citizens, for the first time in history, to vote in the midterms with their smartphones. And all votes that were cast had a voter verified digital receipt. So, as soon as you cast your vote you got a ballot receipt that showed you exactly how you voted so you could verify that your vote was cast, was counted as cast.

So, there was also an audit trail so that the jurisdiction could con--conduct a very rigorous post-election audit. So those pieces are also very important but this is a huge game changer for re-enfranchising this demographic that lives overseas and struggles with receiving mail and--and quite frankly, emailing your ballot to your county clerk is not a very secure, as Jonathan said, process. There's a copy that's made and your name is attached so you really relinquish your right to anonymity and what's actually happening on the ground is that jurisdiction is receiving your emailed ballot and hand copying all of your selections onto a paper ballot that can be tabulated. I don't know if many people know that but that's truly what's happening.

So for coun--for states that have a large portion of these overseas citizens, the amount of human labor doing that process and the potential for human error is quite large.

SHAPIRO: And last--last question, what misconceptions do you hear about blockchain-based voting and how do you respond to them?

BRASETH: Yeah, one thing I want to mention is I want to make sure to differentiate that we are not just blockchain voting. Blockchain is one piece of the puzzle but the other pieces of the puzzle are equally as important to factor into the equation. So, we only operate with the latest classes of smartphones, which smartphone hardware technology has mostly become ubiquitous and the security measures are--are very, very good. So we leverage the biometric capabilities of the smartphone along with cryptography and then blockchain is the piece that, in our view, provides three really main values; the first is data storage. As was mentioned earlier, rather than being housed on one single server, this is distributed across multiple servers.

The second piece is, auditability. So, for the first time--so we had Denver also pilot this in May with their municipal elections, so overseas citizens voted for the mayor on--with Voatz. And we held, for the first time, a citizens public audit where the jurisdiction was able to compare the voter verify of all digital receipts with the actual ballots that were tabulated with the data on the blockchain. So we built a tool to visualize the blockchain where every single vote transaction could be audited; and that's a key piece is--is, again, to reinforce that trust. And the last piece is transparency. So, you go to vote right now, do you know that it's counted and do you know that it's counted correctly? A lot of us just assume that it is but we don't really know and so we're building towards a scenario where for the first time, as a voter, you and only you, can audit your own vote and say, that's my vote on the blockchain, that's exactly how I voted and also do that without revealing your anonymity.

And the last piece I'll mention very quickly is, it's important for me to mention that we use a very specific type of blockchain called a public permissioned network which is different than what you hear about in bitcoin where anybody can participate and run a--a node, is what they're called. So in our case, it's a public permissioned network where anybody running a node has to go through a very rigorous process to do that. But what it enables is that we can make sure that all the nodes are, for example, operating in the United States and that it can most closely mirror the way elections are currently run and have both political parties running a node, non-profits, auditors, universities to be able to distribute and mirror how elections are run today.

SHAPIRO: Thank you Hillary.

JOHNSON: Rob, if I could just interrupt?

SHAPIRO: Of course.

JOHNSON: I--I've seen some of the feedback that Voatz, which is spelled V-O-A-T-Z, has gotten from overseas military personnel, o--overseas foreign exchange students, universally they praise how easy it is to use. What if we could do that for people here? You know, you show up at work, you see someone has got an I Voted sticker on, no one in this room doesn't know when the elections are, that's why you're here in Washington, D.C., but most of America is like, ah, oh, today's voting, we've got to go stand in line at the junior high school or at the library to wait and wait. They can sit in their office or they could be on a plane and vote and be done, done. I think we could increase participation in election by a lot with this technology.

SHAPIRO: Thank you, Jonathan. Next I'm going to turn to Trent Larson. Trent, your enterprise uses blockchain technology to help people get secure title to land holdings in developing countries and in hard to survey rural areas of developed nations. Tell us both why this is important and how do you do it?

LARSON: Okay, I'm--I'll just start with the why. Yeah, that's--it--it--it is important and I'm sure you've seen in the news problems with refugees where they get displaced and then how you go back and reclaim what you had before. There's mass problems all across Africa with trust in some of the systems where--that are supposed to secure your land rights and your land tenure and so that's our focus. We mostly focus in third world countries. And our hope is to build trust in these systems and these registries that the people independently, individually can interact with. So that's a little bit of background.

Let me start with some of the technology because I think it's important to emphasize that you all use cryptography every time you get online and you make a purchase because of the lock that is on the top of your browser shows that you have an encrypted connection. That encryption is one of the basics of watching and bitcoin technology. So what we are doing is getting those encryption tools in the hands of the people, the individuals. And so there's three primary ways that we are helping specifically in some African projects. The first is with systematic lands titling. So this is where Zambia has recognized that people are moving into, and--and residing in, areas where they haven't previously recorded (PH) anything and so it's just been many, many years of people living in their own settlements. The government is finally realizing, you know, whether it would be wrong of somebody to kick them out. Let's record and help them secure that. So, we go out and we incent people on the ground to actually take surveys of--and look at documents and take pictures of documents and people and their houses. They send that in and the registrar will stamp with that cryptographic signature.

So from then on, they can go and point to some place on an open permissions ledger and say, yeah, they stamped this particular plane of land. That's the first way. Second way is a combination of the individual and the registrar where I, as a seller, have recorded what my properties are on the public registry so I'm going to initiate a transaction and so I signed it with my own cryptographic signature that nobody else has but I've registered it.

So, pass the transaction to the buyer. The buyer, if they agree to the terms, and maybe he's agreed that he's received the keys, then we'll sign. Maybe there's a little back and forth while the funds are settled. The signatures then get passed to the registrar and the registrar looks at the workflow, hey, does this pass all of my requirements and do these people really own that property? Okay, I will put my stamp on it and so it's a third stamp. So they each are participating in this transaction. And it's this trust lever that Jonathan had that's making it so that they can each trust one another.

The third way, this is directly in between people and, you know, the first story I told where we'd go into these informal settlements where they haven't been recorded before, they--when we do that, we want to make sure that their neighbors agree with them. So, we have to do this arduous process and go back into the area, put huge maps up on the wall, let them go through paperwork and say, okay, this was me, okay, and do you have a problem with any of these neighbors boundaries that are on your place? No. Okay, go ahead and sign. Again, what if we can, as they're taking the surveys, show that hey, these are what your neighbors claimed as the boundaries, do you agree or disagree? Okay, I agree, then let's put your signature on there, cryptographic signature, and now you've got this social support for that, all those claims. And that's something they can show a year or five years down the road and show, hey, you know, I lived here and--and it builds that history which is--is the documentation.

So, this is--these are a little bit different than what you typically hear about bitcoin. It's--we have this transaction of tokens of value which is a great use case but what we're building these mostly built on, hey, we have signatures and we're reporting the history of (INAUDIBLE). These are often recorded on an open permission-less ledger because, in my case, we want that information to be open to the world.

We don't publish all of the individual's information on there that would have privacy concerns with that. But, when they have the keys, they can go back later and show, oh yeah, this was me if they want to prove it to the bank or prove it to government officials or judges who have a dispute in that area.

SHAPIRO: Thank you. I--I should mention, the World Bank actively supports Medici Land Governance's activities and five African countries. As an economist, there are hundreds of millions of poor people in Africa, in Asia, in Latin America, who are sitting on plots of land that they and their ancestors have been sitting on for two, three, four, ten generations. They can never leave because they have no title to that land. And if they leave, it's gone. They can never sell it. This is--this is a--land titling is one of the most fundamental aspects of development and so the work they're doing, in my view, is God's work.

JOHNSON: And--and Rob, I just want to comment on that. It--it's hard for us to fathom that you can't prove you own your land but that's the way in most of the developing world. If you can't prove you own it, you can't sell it, you can't demise it to your kids and, importantly, you can't borrow against it. Every entrepreneur I know, starts their business with a loan on a--on a second mortgage. This is way to provide great aid to the developing world because we take dead capital, land that's not titled, and we make it alive.

SHAPIRO: Right.

JOHNSON: That's how they jump to the 21st Century.

SHAPIRO: Right.

LARSON: And--and I just want to add a story to that. When you are unable, not just to get loans or anything, but when you see your neighbors have had their land taken away arbitrarily, then you're not very secure in what you've got and how much motivation do you have to improve that, to make a long-term investment in your community. It's hard. So once we get that security in the whole area, that's where you really see things take off.

SHAPIRO: I think we're beginning to see the ways in which blockchain is changing the world. Next we're going to go to Alan--Alan Konevsky who is one of the leaders of tZERO, a leading blockchain-based capital markets company. You apply blockchain technologies to creating and trading financial assets. So you're building a blockchain-based capital market. We already had the world's most advanced and developed capital markets. What can a blockchain-based version contribute?

KONEVSKY: Absolutely. Thanks for the question, I'm delighted to be here. I--I think really, and--and one of the challenges with thinking about blockchain is often because, you know, there isn't a first principle and frame of reference. And I think the one that Jon started with, trust, helps here as well. And we've talked about it, including context (PH) and land registration, I think, trust as the first principle really helps them to span the application blockchain of good application and bad application across a number of use cases.

And so, for capital markets, you have an ecosystem and, incidentally, while it's also just a good yardstick of which to evaluate new technologies generally, if it is something that's going through a fundamental problem that people have been experiencing for as long as they've been keeping within the society and it's aiming to do it better; it's probably a good idea.

And so in this case, looping back to trust, and capital markets, you know, since the development of the current regulatory and operational framework of Wall Street starting in the 30's and then going through the 70's, you--you've come up with a system that enables investors to trust each other largely through a combination of intermediation and--and you have multiple layers of regulated intermediaries that have to satisfy certain requirements, hold certain capital, comply with certain rules, influence certain types of people, subject their books and records to examination supervision by governmental agencies of self-regulatory organizations and it's through those layers of intermediation, and you hear, you know, Jonathan used the terms broker dealers, clearing firms, transfer agents, center clearing counterparties, stock exchanges and others. The idea is that by forcing the transactions to flow through that funnel of intermediation, you are helping people trust that at the end of the day, I'm going to get what I'm paying for and I'm going to get--I'm going to get the proceeds of what I'm selling. Or I'm going to get what I invested in, and I'm going to have reasonable likelihood that my capital subjective, you know, the long end of the sharp stick caveat is going to get, you know, is going to--is going to see a referral.

Intermediation, however, as a solution to trust brings with it friction, brings with it cost, brings with it delays, brings with it, asymmetries of access and information and therefore potential for manipulation and mischief. And that's really what--what we're trying to address when you look at the Wall Street ecosystem and I think it applies globally as well outside of the United States as well. Honestly, this is the frame of reference globally for capital markets whether--when it comes to raising capital or trading capital as you are--you are bringing a substitute mechanism much how in the voting context or land registration for building that trust. So instead of intermediation, you have a permissioned or permission-less ledger that allows securities to be issued and then trade in the way that produces instant settlement, produces visibility into the capital structure of the company, produces a--an instrument that can be far more flexible than traditional stocks or bonds or other kind of--more or less cookie-cutter tools that you have if you are a company looking to raise capital or if you're an investor looking to deploy the assets that are sitting around to productive uses.

You can--you can create instruments that are--that are--that are very smart and that--and that can adjust the particular behaviors that you are looking to incentives and disincentivize. They can have compliance mechanisms built into it so from a regulatory perspective, if something is not meant to go into a retirees account, it can never go into a retirees account, no matter how smooth talking the salesman is. And I think--so those are sort of the front-end benefits and then it's helpful to think about it as a front-end benefits of creating instruments that are more malleable, more flexible, smarter, have regulation built into their DNA that give access to assets that, before, were largely reserved to institutions of very wealthy investors. So there's democratization of capital that's involved here as well where now you can take something, whether it's a big real estate project or--or something else that's largely held back from the--the public markets and most of the value creation is--is--is--is--is reserved for private investors and cut it up into smaller pieces and obviously ensuring regulatory compliance give investors an opportunity to participate in that value creation.

And then there are the backend benefits that come with enabling near instantaneous trading and settlement and--and--and clearing ability to trade these instruments seamlessly, globally, across marketplaces that--that really don't exist now so--

SHAPIRO: So a blockchain-based capital market would mean that lots of people could participate in early funding of companies rather than a select group of investment bankers and very large investors. And it's kind of like the next stage of Kickstarter in that respect. And, you know, I--I--my research has shown a long time ago that some time ago that worldwide banks charge about $2 trillion a year in fees for various kinds of transfers from checks to other kinds of transfers.

And security houses charge a comparable amount; about half. My estimate is about half of those costs could be eliminated through blockchain. That's trillions of dollars.

(LAUGHTER)

That's a large incentive for a very fast-growing market.

JOHNSON: Well, that's just common every time this--this goes to the bitcoin, or the cryptocurrencies. Every time you swipe a credit card there is a 2 percent to 3 percent to 5 percent fee that the credit card processor is taking. With bitcoin, that doesn't exist. And what does that mean? It means lowering your prices is what it means and so, again, I think this is a way every--when--when Alan talks about friction the middlemen caused, friction, number one, is money. They always take their piece. We can take that out with blockchain. Friction number two is time. It takes time to get your money if you sold something or if your good if you bought it. Friction number three is mistake or mischief.

People figuring out how to game the system to commit fraud, or, inadvertently making mistakes they've caused you and me, compliance people, regulators, tons and tons of time.

SHAPIRO: Before I'm going to open it to questions, I want to ask Jonathan one other question and that is, you know, you run a portfolio--we--portfolio of around 20 companies, blockchain companies, we've heard about voting and land governance and capital markets. If you could just briefly tell us other areas that--where blockchain is beginning to make a mark?

JOHNSON: Banking the unbanked and the U.S., 8 percent of the population doesn't have a bank account. 26 percent are under-banked. They're using check cashing companies all the time. In the Caribbean that's 40 percent of the south--South America, it's 70 percent in--in Africa it's 90 percent that don't have banks. Digital wallets, using blockchain technology. I think will enter the 21st Century to have digital currency so they could buy things online; so they don't have to store their money in their sock drawer and worry that it's going to get stolen.

Identity; being able to prove who you are in a cryptographically secure way without giving a bunch of trivial arcana (PH) that proves that you are you. Frankly, if I know your mother's maiden name, your second grade school and your first pets name, I can probably prove that I am you. That's wrong. We can do that with--we can do that in a self-sovereign identity way.

Supply chain; making sure farmers get paid quickly, making sure we know the providence of goods so when you buy a Coach bag online, you know you're getting a Coach bag and you're not getting some knockoff. Monitoring--monitoring agriculture so when there's a recall on lettuce, we're not recalling all of the lettuce, we're knowing where the contaminated farm was that got Representative Soto sick. He ate some bad lettuce and (INAUDIBLE).

(LAUGHTER)

We could be pinpointing these. There are great, great use cases for blockchain.

SHAPIRO: Thank you. And now some questions. The young lady first because you--your hand was up first.

QUESTION: Okay. Well, thank you for being here. This has been really enlightening. So, I'm just thinking with the revolution of blockchain, and--and it seems like the prevalence of it in order to be effective, what are the unin--unintended consequences that you foresee happening? For example, when the internet boomed and it became a very close part of our lives, there have been a lot of consequences that we've seen starting from data, our privacy, mental health, all of that, what are some unintended consequences of blockchain technology that you are seeing?

JOHNSON: I'm ready to answer, unless someone else wants to? I mean, I--I think one--I think it solves some of the unintended consequences of the internet. I think our data gets more private and secure and that's good. I think there's going to be disintermediation of certain industries. You know, when the car came along, buggy manufacturers went away. There are a lot of trust intermediaries; whether they're brokers or title agents who are, you know, they're going to move out of place. But as it's been with every new technology, it tends to create more jobs (INAUDIBLE). So I think that's one.

I think there's a risk of over-regulation. Bill mentioned earlier, the Supply Chain Caucus and Representative Soto, like a light touch regulatory piece. One of the great things that Bill Clinton did with the internet story was he said, we want this technology to develop free and unfettered regulation. It doesn't mean it didn't--there aren't--there aren't actions that don't get regulated that use blockchain technology, frankly, capital markets are always going to be regulated at some point. Transfer of title is going to be regulated. Voting; who gets to vote? That's always regulated, but don't regulate the technology, I think that's a big concern. Did that address your question?

QUESTION: I think just--I mean, you've been bringing it--bringing it back to votes, I think that's a really creative way to do it, but I already see so many communities being blocked out from accessing this voting app, right? It's who doesn't have government stated IDs, who doesn't have access to the latest technology or to the latest edition of phones. Like I see the pros, but I also see the cons.

BRASETH: Absolutely! I think as I had mentioned earlier, it will be a very long time before this becomes the only option to vote. This isn't replacing the traditional methods of you being able to go to a polling place and cast your vote that way. And I think--I think we are seeing a continued trend where more than 85 percent of U.S. American's have a smartphone, not just old phone but a smartphone and so I think we'll continue to see that increase given projections. But to name what your concern is, in terms of voter ID laws, in order to have the convenience of voting no matter your circumstance or wherever you are, we have to find a day to be able to ensure that you are who you say you are and so we have to have that be a tradeoff in this instance. And I think what we're seeing is that a lot of people are saying yes, this is so much more convenient and much more available to the way that I--we all live, in many ways, so many of us live mobile lives. So, yeah.

JOHNSON: I think it has to be additive initially, it can't be replacing.

BRASETH: Yeah.

JOHNSON: It needs to be additive.

KONEVSKY: Yeah, I think that's--I think that's right. I mean, that certainly has been the experience in the capital market space where this is a journey and it's a journey that's incremental and iterative where you look at the existing checks and balances ecosystem, we've talked about intermediation, we've talked about regulation that supports that intermediation and as you look to--while continuing to address the same critical priorities around investor protection and other topics to have technology do the job of the intermediaries, with the benefits that come with it, whether it's faster, cheaper and--and more accessible, safer, it is a journey that is incremental in narrative and where things are going to be riding side-by-side for a period of time.

So from a test and learn perspective, you are going to be able to identify the pain points when you're talking about it as you look to, you know, at the end of the day emerged into the 2.0 ecosystem. But there is going to--you know, there's going to be a transitional phase and I think it probably applies across our use cases as well as other use cases in general voting.

SHAPIRO: There is no doubt that like the internet, this is a disruptive technology. Yes?

QUESTION: With respect to votes, what is the interface with the list of registered voters? How does that work?

BRASETH: So the question was, what is the interface with the list of registered voters? So we work very, very closely with the jurisdiction that's piloting the technology. So, thus far, each jurisdiction has decided to do it a little bit differently but the process for you as a voter remains the same where you have to apply to request an absentee ballot and at that moment, if your jurisdiction allows you to use votes you would indicate that rather than receiving it via mail or email, you want to receive a mobile ballot and they keep the list and then are able to send that to us for the invitation for the voter to be able to download and then their identity verification process is back-checked against that list to make sure that they requested and they requested it via mobile, indeed.

SHAPIRO: Yes?

QUESTION: I just have a question in regards to the capital markets, again, it's similar to the first question that was asked but in terms of like removing that intermediary, how do you--how would you prevent something an increase like insider trading once you start to remove that kind of that kind of--those safety procedures and how would regulation change to account for that?

KONEVSKY: Well, I think that as you look to replace intermediation from institutions and individuals with technology while, again, looking to address the same priorities that you have currently from a policy perspective, whether it is lack of asymmetries and access to information influencing trading behavior, for example, whether it is investor suitability, you--you're going to be looking at a couple of things, one is you're going to be looking at the design of the instruments themselves and the instruments are going to be designed in a fairly immutable DNA level that will prevent certain behaviors from happening. So, for example, if you are a corporate insider and you have access to information, you will not be able to initiate a transaction even--no matter how hard you try unless you are within a period where you deem, from a legal policy perspective, to be permitted to trade because, for example, a company just brought out its annual quarterly report.

And so you are going to be looking--yeah, I think technology design and security is going to be critical. You know, I think part of it is--and I think it comes up in any technology conversation, you know, we--we tend to have a fairly rosy view of what institutions and people do and that's what's happening now; you have a set of rules that's largely policed from a regulatory agency, self-regulatory agencies and regulated private entities and their employees. And, you know, as Jonathan was saying, there are mistakes, there's mischief and so the yardstick isn't necessarily perfection at this point and I think the view is that technology will eliminate a lot of the human contributors to that mischief, to those mistakes. So--and I think that's--you know, that's the answer.

SHAPIRO: Well, we have time for one more question. Go ahead.

QUESTION: Hi, thanks for coming. I have a question kind of more on the money side. So, do you think that we'll ever see a world where the governments are issuing cryptocurrencies as their state currency and then if you do see that, what type of network would they run, would that state-run cryptocurrency use and then what implications do you think that that would have on monetary policy for those countries?

SHAPIRO: By cryptocurrency you mean just a digital currency?

QUESTION: Yeah, digital currencies, state-run digital currency.

JOHNSON: So one of the companies that's in our holdings is a company called Bitt, B-I-T-T. It's currently working with the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank to help it issue a central bank digital currency. So the answer to your first question, do I think we'll ever see a world where central banks are issuing digital currency is, yes, I think we will. And I think one of the--what's the consequences of that? Frankly, I think it makes things cheaper, 10 percent printing cost, 8 percent printing costs are--are created (PH) and bills goes away. I think it makes transfer a lot easier, if you're populous (PH) has digital wallets that government funds can be sent to, you do it without a lot of bank transfer fees. If a central bank is is--issuing the currency, it still has the ability to do what it does today, decide when to print faster, decide when to print slower unless they decided to print, that seems to be all the time, but it's faster or slower when they--they decide to print.

So, I still think central bankers will have a role, a big role, maybe I'll have another--a cheaper way to issue currency. Does that address the question?

SHAPIRO: Let me just say, you know, with any general purpose innovation, whether it was the internet or computers or blockchain, what we first see are the ways in which the technology changes existing activities and existing operations. The next stage is entrepreneurs figure out entirely new things to do with this technology. That's why it's so exciting to be at the beginning of this new general purpose technology.

I just want to give everyone on the panel a chance to make a closing remark or two and we'll start with you Hillary. We'll go right down the--

BRASETH: Thank you again so much and it's also been wonderful to learn more about all that you are working on. I guess to close, I would be very curious to hear if any of you work in offices or spaces that are interested in exploring what a pilot might look like and also I think in terms of their relationship with government, you know, all of you work in this large marble building and at times things move slowly or more slowly than others. And so I think we're really interested in what would it look like for folks to really pioneer what an innovative spirit within our government would look like, and so I'd love to talk with anybody that's interested in learning more about that and also how might we foster deeper relationships between startups and government from just relationally-based to what might funding sources look like as well?

LARSON: Yeah, we're interested too in government partnerships, mostly with the countries, but if you've got connections, that's great.

JOHNSON: You're doing something in Wyoming right now.

LARSON: That is true, Wyoming has a pilot program, we've gone live with that just this summer, so it's (INAUDIBLE). So, I will also put out there that we're on cryptocurrency, (INAUDIBLE), we've got companies already flew in from New York and they're fleeing the U.S. because of their--there's things like the horrendous IRS ruling where every token swapped has--has to be taxed. I don't want entrepreneurial 8-year old Jonathan Johnson to be swapping tokens with his friends and then have to go through that kind of rigmarole, you know, let innovation start and--and at least get that beginning.

KONEVSKY: Yeah, absolutely, very grateful to be here and share our flaws. I think the point about regulatory evolution, as much as we talk about technological and strategic evolution behind this technology and its applications is also political and regulatory--it is going to be evolution as a (INAUDIBLE) evolution and it is going to be iterative and incremental and that's a good thing and it's a good thing with respect to (INAUDIBLE) question I was asked before about how do we test and learn messengers (PH) of consequences but also in terms of really overhauling, to your point, something that has been around for a long time, has worked well and will work infinitely better.

I think one of the--you know, of the questions Will asked about it kind of--this in the financial crisis. And if you had, you know, if you had this when the 2008, 2009 events happened, would things have been different? And look, you can second guess this to the cows come home, and the financial crisis was such as multifactorial--and it's hard to reduce it to a singularity but if you think about it as a crisis of trust including a crisis of trust in institutions, the intermediaries that we talked about, including financial institutions that, you know, (INAUDIBLE) explanations, you know, (INAUDIBLE) liquidity and other things that--that have a lot of (INAUDIBLE) fundamentally crisis of trust.

Then having an ecosystem that had more transparent, or transparency, for regulators, for other market participants in the--for example, portfolios held by Lehman and others financial institutions, had ability to do real-time valuation of assets. Gave--had instruments that were--that--that were designed in a way to automatically adjust to events of great (PH) value themselves that minimize the ability to commit loan fraud so that the mortgage-backed portfolios of that, to some extent, have that mortgages that could, you know, have a lesser likelihood of a company because loan fraud was prevented whether through digital identity with centralized credit check or--of credit checking from the (INAUDIBLE) blockchain-based databases, right. And--and, you know, there--there are a lot of factors here that probably could answer that things could have been different.

JOHNSON: First, thanks again PPI, this has been fantastic. I never come to a meeting with a member of Congress where there are staff without an ask. Here's my ask. This is the time you get out your pens. Use us as a resource. As your offices think about regulation and legislation that touches blockchain, we have 19 companies with product in production, votes actually being cast in U.S. elections using blockchain technology, land titles being recorded and transferred using blockchain technology, securities being transferred using blockchain technology. If you want to know how it will affect boots on the ground workers in real industries; we're here to answer that question; Medici Ventures, named after the Italian renaissance family, the Medici's which supposedly brought double-entry bookkeeping accounting to the West--

(LAUGHTER)

--became great philanthropists afterwards.

(LAUGHTER)

JOHNSON: --going to shoot me down right there.

(LAUGHTER)

We're a multiple-entry distributed ledgers. That's how you can remember us. We'd love to help, we'd love to be your resource, back in Washington frequently. Please reach out to us so we can help you.

SHAPIRO: Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

MARSHALL: Thank you, Rob, well done. Lovely. Great conversation. Thank you all very much, that was--(INAUDIBLE).

BRASETH: Rob, thank you so much.

value.Title: Progressive Policy Institute: Winning Where It Matters - New Survey Probes Opinion in Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania

Extracts.SummaryText: ... * By a huge margin, (70-30%), voters see tech companies "as examples of America 's great strengths in innovation and entrepreneurship" rather than as companies that have "grown too big and powerful and need to be broken up." * Voters strongly prefer tougher regulation to dismantling big tech companies. * By a wide margin (69-31%), battleground voters would prefer to spend more to help Americans without college degrees get higher skills and better jobs rather than making all colleges tuition-free ...

urn:contentItem:5YC5-9HV1-JC11-11NH-00000-00Progressive Policy Institute: Winning Where It Matters - New Survey Probes Opinion in Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania2020-03-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisProgressive Policy Institute: Winning Where It Matters - New Survey Probes Opinion in Michigan, Wisconsin and PennsylvaniaTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Progressive Policy Institute issued the following news release:

Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania put Donald Trump over the top in the Electoral College in 2016. Turning those states blue again should be a top strategic priority for those working to unseat Trump in 2020.

In recognition of their pivotal status, the Progressive Policy Institute commissioned Democratic pollster and strategist Pete Brodnitz to take a deep dive into voter attitudes in these three battleground states. His Expedition Strategies poll also focuses on swing voters, including those who voted for Barack Obama in 2012 and Trump in 2016.

The report sheds light on key issues likely to be on the minds of Michigan voters in next Tuesday's presidential primaries. It finds that progressives have some arguments that resonate in Michigan and the other two states -- particularly their critique of how wealth is accumulating at the top and the need for wealthy individuals and companies to pay more in taxes.

On the other hand, battleground voters approve of Trump's handling of the economy, with swing voters being especially positive. And the progressive push for Medicare for All is generally unpopular in these states, and has the potential to turn what should be the single best Democratic strength into a liability. To illustrate the danger here - one in four Democrats (24%) "fear" a Democratic push for a government-run health care system more than they fear Republican efforts to "kill Obamacare."

"It's health care, stupid," said PPI President Will Marshall of the issue voters in these states identify as their top concern. "The key for Democrats is to shift voter attention from the Medicare for All sideshow to the Trump Republicans' continuing assault on Obamacare and Medicaid," he added.

By better than 2-1 (69-31%), battleground voters favor changes that build on the current, public-private health insurance system to a single, government-run health plan. That's true of Democrats too, who favor the former by a solid, 18-point margin.

Among voters generally, Democrats have an eight-point advantage on handling health care. Among swing voters, however, they have an eight-point deficit. And by 52-48, all voters say they are more worried about Democratic calls for a government-run health care system than Republican efforts to kill Obamacare.

Here are other relevant findings as the presidential contest moves to Michigan and then Wisconsin and Pennsylvania:

* By a whopping 72 points, (86-14%), all battleground voters say the U.S. is better off when we encourage trade, and by more than 2-1, they say the same about trade agreements.

* In Michigan, voters by a 24-point margin agree that trade agreements make the United States better off.

* Only eight percent of voters in the three battleground states consider climate change the most important issue.

* Only 30 percent of voters favor an immediate ban on fracking for natural gas, while 70 percent do not favor such a ban.

* Asked to name the biggest economic risk if Trump wins re-election, most voters choose "the wealthy will get richer and the rest left out."

* Battleground state Voters here strongly favor a national industrial strategy to create more manufacturing jobs in the United States

* By a huge margin, (70-30%), voters see tech companies "as examples of America's great strengths in innovation and entrepreneurship" rather than as companies that have "grown too big and powerful and need to be broken up."

* Voters strongly prefer tougher regulation to dismantling big tech companies.

* By a wide margin (69-31%), battleground voters would prefer to spend more to help Americans without college degrees get higher skills and better jobs rather than making all colleges tuition-free

* Voters favor an innovative PPI idea -- a change in Social Security that would award benefits based on how many years a person worked rather than how much they earned throughout their career (69-31%)

This poll surveyed 1,500 registered voters in Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, and was conducted February 6-18, 2020.

Read the full analysis from PPI President Will Marshall here (https://www.progressivepolicy.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/PPI_SwingVoters_PollNarrative.pdf).

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y51-C821-JCB9-4051-00000-00Progressives ramp up fight against Facebook2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisPg. 14Progressives ramp up fight against FacebookBy Emily Birnbaum

A broad array of progressive groups are stepping up their battle against Facebook, creating a loose coalition to hit back at the largest social network in the world over allegations that it has harmed their ability to organize.

The groups, representing a large swath of the progressive left, say they have been unfairly caught up in Facebook's efforts to crack down on fake accounts and election manipulation, leaving them scrambling to maintain their Facebook pages and millions of followers.

Members of the Campaign to Regulate and Break Up Big Tech, a new coalition in the nascent stages of organizing, have been meeting with regulators and lawmakers after direct talks with top Facebook officials broke down, according to the groups.

"It became increasingly clear that dialogue was not going to get us very far," a progressive strategist involved with organizing the coalition told The Hill.

"That's why an increasing number of groups have come together to jointly strategize, to coordinate planning to achieve those two goals: regulation of the platform on the one hand, and breaking up Big Tech," the strategist added.

Conservatives have been more public about their criticism as they claim Facebook routinely censors right-wing voices, allegations that the company has vociferously denied. But some on the left have been leveling that accusation behind closed doors.

Representatives from groups including March for Our Lives, MoveOn, Fight for 15, Social Security Works, Daily Kos and other left-wing heavyweights first began meeting with top Facebook officials just after the midterm elections in 2018.

Progressives who spoke to The Hill said they asked for the meetings after Facebook removed or restricted many of their pages amid the company's October 2018 purge of spammy political content.

"The biggest thing was, 'Clarify the rules for us,' " Chris Reeves, a longtime organizer who currently serves as a Kansas Democratic committeeman and participated in a meeting over the phone, told The Hill. "Because nobody seems to understand, and they won't tell us what the actual hard-and-fast rules of their platform are."

Reeves said many of the left-wing activists felt frustrated as they saw their engagement numbers go down while conservatives seemed to dominate Facebook.

The meetings with progressives, which have not been previously reported, spanned months and involved high-level Facebook officials, including the company's top lobbyist, Kevin Martin; head of global policy Monika Bickert; head of cybersecurity policy Nathaniel Gleicher; director of external affairs Lindsay Elin; and others, according to sources involved in the talks.

A Facebook spokesperson confirmed the company held multiple meetings with the groups.

"We appreciate the feedback we've received in meetings with these organizations, along with the chance to describe our efforts to be fully transparent in how we operate," the spokesperson told The Hill in a statement.

"Our policies are outlined in great detail ¯ publicly ¯ as are our enforcement practices and the process people can use to appeal our decisions," the spokesperson added.

By the end of January of this year, many of the groups were left feeling dejected and personally aggrieved, alleging that Facebook officials had taken no substantive action about their concerns.

"It felt like they were approaching it like, 'OK, this is one of those days we have to stick it out and get yelled at by these people,' but they don't actually do anything," Charlie Mirsky, a co-founder of the powerful gun violence prevention group March for Our Lives, told The Hill.

Carolyn Fiddler, the communications director for left-leaning news organization Daily Kos, told The Hill her organization has been frustrated with Facebook's lack of transparency over algorithmic changes. She said they are currently negotiating over whether Facebook will include Daily Kos as a Facebook News partner, a source of tension as Facebook has already named right-leaning Breitbart News as a participant.

Many organizers across the political spectrum know Facebook is a vital tool to organize, amplify their messages and ask for donations. But increasingly over the past year, popular left-wing political pages have been taken down suddenly or had their reach limited by Facebook, the sources said, as the platform tries to act more aggressively against bots and spam following the 2016 presidential election. Right-wing pages have also been taken down and affected by the changes.

Political activists for years coordinated campaigns on Facebook by having multiple pages and groups post the same message at the same time. But after 2016, when Russian operatives were able to successfully push disinformation campaigns across the platform, some groups said they felt they were punished for using that strategy.

At a meeting in January, Gleicher told the groups they'd been caught up in a "net" as Facebook's systems worked to take down "coordinated inauthentic behavior," the platform's term for online activity that seems spammy or driven by bots, multiple sources confirmed.

The groups asked Facebook to whitelist their organizations in order to ensure they did not get caught up in future efforts to take down fake campaigns, two sources said. But officials have not followed up on that request.

On Jan. 29, the groups delivered a set of demands to Facebook mainly focused on "transparency," according to a copy of the demands obtained by The Hill. They asked Facebook to publish "clear, precise rules" that would apply to "pages and publishers of all sizes and ideological orientations" and asked for the platform to offer more specific explanations when pages were taken down.

A Facebook spokesperson pointed out that the company updated its Community Standards in April 2018 to delineate more granular details about where Facebook draws the line and why it removes certain content.

Facebook also notifies individual users, page administrators and group administrators when they violate the company's rules.

The spokesperson also rejected the allegations that Facebook "discourages" sharing posts between pages, but said Facebook has rules against clickbait and spam because people do not want to see it.

After the talks purportedly broke down, representatives with several of the progressive organizations have joined together to form the Campaign to Regulate and Break Up Big Tech, an effort to make the case to lawmakers and regulators that Facebook can only be reined in through regulation or a total breakup of the company.

The progressives participate in a weekly call to discuss and strategize around antitrust issues, multiple sources confirmed. And the group has brought the anti-Facebook crusade to key lawmakers and at least one state attorney general.

Members have met with Rep. Jan Schakowsky (D-Ill.), who is leading efforts to write an online privacy bill in the House, and House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee staff, who are probing the country's largest tech companies, including Facebook, multiple sources said. They have raised their concerns with Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison (D), one of the 47 attorneys general currently investigating Facebook for antitrust issues, according to two sources. And one source said they are continuing to reach out to other state attorneys general.

"Part of what we're trying to do is help the country see this new form of exploitation for what it is," Aram Fischer, an organizer with Indivisible who participates in the weekly calls from San Francisco, told The Hill. "We seek policy changes that end the exploitation and also promote more transparency."
