urn:contentItem:60F0-8Y11-JCSC-J005-00000-00Promarket Groups Counter Big Tech Competition Worries2020-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisNEWSPromarket Groups Counter Big Tech Competition WorriesJulia Arciga

A trade association for online businesses and a think tank in two research papers released Thursday pushed back against antitrust concerns raised about Facebook and other internet platforms, with both papers arguing the companies are not monopolies. NetCho... A trade association for online businesses and a think tank in two research papers released Thursday pushed back against...

A trade association for online businesses and a think tank in two research papers released Thursday pushed back against antitrust concerns raised about Facebook and other internet platforms, with both papers arguing the companies are not monopolies. NetCho...

A trade association for online businesses and a think tank in two research papers released Thursday pushed back against antitrust concerns raised about Facebook and other internet platforms, with both papers arguing the companies are not monopolies. NetChoice and the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation both played down the concerns surrounding big tech companies even as U.S. and global competition regulators and lawmakers scrutinize the firms. As part of policymakers' inquiries, the heads of Google's parent company, Alphabet; Amazon; Apple; and Facebook are scheduled to testify before a House Judiciary subcommittee next week. NetChoice's report argued that Facebook is nowhere close to a "near-monopoly" and currently faces growing competition, countering points levied in a paper released by the Omidyar Network last month. The Omidyar paper painted a "road map" of an antitrust case that could be waged against Facebook based on analysis conducted by the U.K.'s antitrust regulator, the Competition and Markets Authority. NetChoice argues that Facebook is a "two-sided platform" that must compete for both social media users and advertisers. On the user end, NetChoice claimed that Facebook must fight for eyeballs among competitors that include YouTube, Snapchat, Twitter, Pinterest and TikTok. On the advertising side, it said Facebook's current operations and capabilities were akin to those of a "communications company." Thus, the market Facebook is competing in includes Google, Amazon, AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast. The ITIF said tech firms as a whole were competing "with each other for the scarce attention" of the same users when selling ads, which meant that Google competed with TikTok and Facebook even if it held a dominant position in search engines. The think tank also said the firms competed with television, radio, and newspapers for the same ad dollars and eyeballs. According to NetChoice, the Omidyar Network paper defines the markets too narrowly for Facebook, excluding competitor YouTube and adding together the market shares of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp to arrive at the total 75% share of the U.K. social media market that it touts. "[T]hey go on to define the relevant market so narrowly that their definition might as well be 'Facebook and only Facebook,'" the report read. The NetChoice paper also argues that Facebook will continue to face increasing competition as its target user base gets more dynamic. The social network has had a decline in market share and user time spent on the site since 2015, according to the paper. Facebook now competes with Twitter, TikTok, YouTube, and Snapchat for the attention of today's teenagers, who often use many social media platforms. The ITIF argued that tech firms aren't actually as dominant as they seem when compared to the power of automobile and gas companies in the 1960s. While these large firms do attract large profits, the think tank said the companies did not have significant political or economic power. Both NetChoice and ITIF both took the position that tech companies have engaged in pro-competitive conduct. NetChoice pointed to Facebook's development of "data-backed tools" that give advertisers more value and boost exposure for small publishers, while the ITIF said tech platforms were improving resource use and increasing competition by making the market bigger. Netchoice also pointed to Facebook's acquisition of Instagram, which it claimed made the app better. "Facebook's acquisition made Instagram better, which thereby increased consumer welfare. Once it joined Facebook, the platform went from being a small player with few users to one of the most popular in the country," the paper read. The Omidyar Network paper was pushed towards several government entities last month by the public interest group Public Knowledge. The paper was written by Yale University economics professor Fiona M. Scott Morton, a former chief economist at the DOJ's Antitrust Division, and David C. Dinielli, a senior adviser with the Omidyar Network. Recent reports said that Morton also has been working as an adviser for Amazon and Apple. Facebook and the Omidyar Network did not immediately respond to requests for comment Thursday. --Additional reporting by Hannah Albarazi, Allison Grande, and Nadia Dreid. Editing by Peter Rozovsky.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8P-09W1-JBKR-R3W1-00000-00Prominent architect, Silicon Valley investor push for Sidewalk Labs rethink; Privacy2019-06-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. FP2Prominent architect, Silicon Valley investor push for Sidewalk Labs rethink; PrivacyGeoff Zochodne And Sean CraigFinancial PostTOrONTO

The critics of a big-tech-backed waterfront project in Toronto now include a renowned Canadian architect and a prominent Silicon Valley investor, both of whom are prodding Toronto city council to take action.

In a letter addressed to Mayor John Tory and his executive council ahead of their scheduled meeting Thursday, Abel Joseph "Jack" Diamond, a five-time winner of the Governor General's Medal in Architecture, asked the city to "reverse" the approach Alphabet Inc.-owned Sidewalk Labs (a sibling firm to Google) has taken to its proposed development of the eastern waterfront.

Diamond - who was made an Officer of the Order of Canada in 1995 - argued that "urban development is not Google or Sidewalk Labs'expertise" and that "the process followed by Sidewalk Labs was inverted," which he says is a result of Sidewalk's slow and continuing rollout of the project's governing principles.

"The principles governing the development should have been established before planning and design was undertaken," wrote Diamond.

"These factors include the question of privacy of the individual in the public, as well as the private realm; who benefits from any data collected; and the ownership of the information gathered; how will development be financed; and managed; whether real estate taxes are exclusively, as they should be, accrued by the City; and who pays for the infrastructure that makes development possible."

Diamond's letter followed one from Roger McNamee - which noted he was an early investor in Facebook Inc. and a mentor to its founder, Mark Zuckerberg - saying the smart city project is "the most highly evolved version" yet of what a Harvard professor dubbed "surveillance capitalism."

According to McNamee, Google will "claim the right to exploit the data" it collects any way it wants.

"I am writing to ask that you abandon the project with Alphabet's Sidewalk Labs on Toronto's waterfront," states his letter. "If it has not done so already, Google will ask for freedom from politics. The corporation's goal is to replace democracy with algorithmic decision-making, believing the latter to be more efficient."

McNamee's letter comes as Sidewalk Labs'participation in Waterfront Toronto's Quayside project has come under increased scrutiny.

Quayside is a 12-acre patch of land for which Sidewalk Labs - selected by Waterfront Toronto as an "Innovation and Funding Partner" - is currently crafting a Master Innovation and Development Plan (MIDP) aimed at transforming the area.

Waterfront Toronto was created by all three levels of government and tasked with overseeing the city's redevelopment along Lake Ontario. (Andrew MacLeod, president and CEO of Financial Post owner Postmedia Network Canada Corp., was recently named to the agency's board of directors.) The agency has yet to receive Sidewalk Labs'proposal, but plans to make public when it does.

The project, however, has faced concerns over how personal data and privacy issues will be handled, with a #BlockSidewalk campaign pushing Waterfront Toronto to "reset" the project. A vote by the agency's board on the Quayside MIDP has reportedly been pushed back to late this year or early next.

In a statement on Twitter, a Sidewalk Labs spokesperson said the company looks "forward to presenting more details of our proposal in the coming weeks" and that the company believes "that this new neighbourhood could in fact set a new standard of privacy and forward-thinking data policy."

A statement from a Sidewalk Labs spokeswoman to Financial Post also pushed back on McNamee's concerns, saying he "does not seem very familiar with what Sidewalk Labs is actually proposing." The company cited a mention in the letter of facial recognition, a technology Sidewalk Labs says it had already ruled out.

"As we have made clear, we believe that data collected in public space must be overseen and closely controlled by an independent and publicly accountable Data Trust, not Sidewalk Labs, Google, or any private company," Keerthana Rang wrote in an email.

"We believe that this district will in fact set a new standard of privacy and forward-thinking data policy, and we look forward to presenting more details of our plan in the coming weeks."

Diamond, though, challenged whether or not the technology Sidewalk Labs will bring to the Quayside development will be at all innovative. Of the company's proposal to have freight delivery and waste collection through underground tunnels, Diamond says that "was built in Chicago in the 19th century."

He calls a proposal to have "building raincoats" that shield structures from weather and regulate temperature "laughable" and a "pathetic rainscreen."

"The building designs illustrated could not be more conventional, not to say boring," adds Diamond.

He closes by saying the Sidewalk Labs "process should be reversed," and that the city should set ground rules "by establishing ownership of data, satisfying the need for personal privacy (ie., no data gathered without the individual's consent) the financial framework, spell out the implementation structure, the composition of the development company, and ownership of all data gathered."

"Above all the City should retain consultants with expertise equivalent to that of Sidewalk Labs, which clearly is not the case at present." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2019 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:5SP0-H351-DXCW-D31J-00000-00Promising 'Bellwether' or Utter Failure? California Passes Landmark Privacy Law for Online Data2018-06-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:08ZLexisNexisPromising 'Bellwether' or Utter Failure? California Passes Landmark Privacy Law for Online Data

Portland: Common Dreams has issued the following press release: While some critics worry the legislation doesn't nearly go far enough, other observers are saying "California could be the bellwether for the privacy movement" after the state legislature on Thursday unanimously passed and Democratic Gov. Jerry Brown signed into law the nation's toughest digital privacy rules. As TechCrunch outlined, once the new law takes effect in January 2020: Businesses must disclose what information it collects, what business purpose it does so for and any third parties it shares that data with. Businesses would be required to comply with official consumer requests to delete that data.

Consumers can opt out of their data being sold, and businesses can't retaliate by changing the price or level of service. Businesses can, however, offer "financial incentives" for being allowed to collect data. California authorities are empowered to fine companies for violations. Even though it could set a new national standard, as Lee Fang reported earlier this week, citing emails obtained by the The Intercept, "lobbyists for the largest tech companies" quiety fought for the "compromise privacy legislation" in order to keep an even stricter measure off the ballot in November. The ballot initiative, Fang wrote, aimed to enable consumers "to opt out of the sale and collection of their personal data," significantly expand "the definition of personal information to include geolocation, biometrics, and browsing history," and even allow "consumers to pursue legal action for violations of the law." The California Consumer Privacy Act (AB375) retains several of the initial provisions from the ballot measure, which had the same name as the bill and was backed by real estate mogul Alastair Mactaggart. However, there are a few key differences. For example, the law requires "the disclosure of only the 'category' of a third-party that receives personal information, instead of the identity of the third-party itself," The Verge noted. "Perhaps most importantly, passing the privacy rules as legislation allows lawmakers to more easily change them, while a ballot measure would be more difficult to amend." Despite the differences, AB375 is similar enough to the ballot initiative that Mactaggart's campaign agreed to withdraw its measure if the governor signed the law by the withdrawal deadline, which he did. "We are thrilled that AB375 has become law. This is a monumental achievement for consumers, with California leading the way in creating unprecedented consumer protections for the rest of the nation," Mactaggart said Thursday. The ACLU of Northern California, meanwhile, was not satisfied with the legislation. "Concern for privacy is at an all-time high in the aftermath of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, and yet California has enacted a law that utterly fails to provide the privacy protections the public has demanded and deserves. Nobody should be fooled to think AB375 properly protects Californians' privacy," said Nicole Ozer, the group's technology and civil liberties director. "This measure was hastily drafted and needs to be fixed," Ozer added. "When that happens next year, effective privacy protections must be included that actually protect against rampant misuse of personal information, make sure that companies cannot retaliate against Californians who exercise their privacy rights, and ensure that Californians can actually enforce their personal privacy rights." The push for stricter privacy measures comes as part of an international wave of efforts to protect consumers' data following recent breaches and abuses by Big Tech. As Wired explained: [AB375 is] similar to the General Data Protection Regulation that went into effect in the European Union last month, but adds to it in crucial ways. Under the GDPR, businesses are required to get users' permission before collecting and storing their data. But the way most companies have designed those opt-in pop-ups, "you really don't have a choice," says Ashkan Soltani, former chief technology officer of the Federal Trade Commission who helped author the ballot initiative.
